BEGIN NOW Stately, plump Buck Mulligan came from the stairhead, bearing a bowl of END
BEGIN NOW lather on which a mirror and a razor lay crossed. END
BEGIN NOW A yellow dressinggown, END
BEGIN NOW ungirdled, was sustained gently behind him on the mild morning air. END
BEGIN NOW He END
BEGIN NOW held the bowl aloft and intoned: END
BEGIN NOW —Introibo ad altare Dei. END
BEGIN NOW Halted, he peered down the dark winding stairs and called out coarsely: END
BEGIN NOW —Come up, Kinch! END
BEGIN NOW Come up, you fearful jesuit! END
BEGIN NOW Solemnly he came forward and mounted the round gunrest. END
BEGIN NOW He faced about END
BEGIN NOW and blessed gravely thrice the tower, the surrounding land and the END
BEGIN NOW awaking mountains. END
BEGIN NOW Then, catching sight of Stephen Dedalus, he bent END
BEGIN NOW towards him and made rapid crosses in the air, gurgling in his throat END
BEGIN NOW and shaking his head. END
BEGIN NOW Stephen Dedalus, displeased and sleepy, leaned his END
BEGIN NOW arms on the top of the staircase and looked coldly at the shaking END
BEGIN NOW gurgling face that blessed him, equine in its length, and at the light END
BEGIN NOW untonsured hair, grained and hued like pale oak. END
BEGIN NOW Buck Mulligan peeped an instant under the mirror and then covered the END
BEGIN NOW bowl smartly. END
BEGIN NOW —Back to barracks! END
BEGIN NOW he said sternly. END
BEGIN NOW He added in a preacher's tone: END
BEGIN NOW —For this, O dearly beloved, is the genuine Christine: body and soul and END
BEGIN NOW blood and ouns. END
BEGIN NOW Slow music, please. END
BEGIN NOW Shut your eyes, gents. END
BEGIN NOW One moment. END
BEGIN NOW A END
BEGIN NOW little trouble about those white corpuscles. END
BEGIN NOW Silence, all. END
BEGIN NOW He peered sideways up and gave a long slow whistle of call, then paused END
BEGIN NOW awhile in rapt attention, his even white teeth glistening here and there END
BEGIN NOW with gold points. END
BEGIN NOW Chrysostomos. END
BEGIN NOW Two strong shrill whistles answered END
BEGIN NOW through the calm. END
BEGIN NOW —Thanks, old chap, he cried briskly. END
BEGIN NOW That will do nicely. END
BEGIN NOW Switch off the END
BEGIN NOW current, will you? END
BEGIN NOW He skipped off the gunrest and looked gravely at his watcher, gathering END
BEGIN NOW about his legs the loose folds of his gown. END
BEGIN NOW The plump shadowed face and END
BEGIN NOW sullen oval jowl recalled a prelate, patron of arts in the middle ages. END
BEGIN NOW A pleasant smile broke quietly over his lips. END
BEGIN NOW —The mockery of it! END
BEGIN NOW he said gaily. END
BEGIN NOW Your absurd name, an ancient Greek! END
BEGIN NOW He pointed his finger in friendly jest and went over to the parapet, END
BEGIN NOW laughing to himself. END
BEGIN NOW Stephen Dedalus stepped up, followed him wearily END
BEGIN NOW halfway and sat down on the edge of the gunrest, watching him still as END
BEGIN NOW he propped his mirror on the parapet, dipped the brush in the bowl and END
BEGIN NOW lathered cheeks and neck. END
BEGIN NOW Buck Mulligan's gay voice went on. END
BEGIN NOW —My name is absurd too: Malachi Mulligan, two dactyls. END
BEGIN NOW But it has a END
BEGIN NOW Hellenic ring, hasn't it? END
BEGIN NOW Tripping and sunny like the buck himself. END
BEGIN NOW We END
BEGIN NOW must go to Athens. END
BEGIN NOW Will you come if I can get the aunt to fork out END
BEGIN NOW twenty quid? END
BEGIN NOW He laid the brush aside and, laughing with delight, cried: END
BEGIN NOW —Will he come? END
BEGIN NOW The jejune jesuit! END
BEGIN NOW Ceasing, he began to shave with care. END
BEGIN NOW —Tell me, Mulligan, Stephen said quietly. END
BEGIN NOW —Yes, my love? END
BEGIN NOW —How long is Haines going to stay in this tower? END
BEGIN NOW Buck Mulligan showed a shaven cheek over his right shoulder. END
BEGIN NOW —God, isn't he dreadful? END
BEGIN NOW he said frankly. END
BEGIN NOW A ponderous Saxon. END
BEGIN NOW He thinks END
BEGIN NOW you're not a gentleman. END
BEGIN NOW God, these bloody English! END
BEGIN NOW Bursting with money END
BEGIN NOW and indigestion. END
BEGIN NOW Because he comes from Oxford. END
BEGIN NOW You know, Dedalus, you END
BEGIN NOW have the real Oxford manner. END
BEGIN NOW He can't make you out. END
BEGIN NOW O, my name for you END
BEGIN NOW is the best: Kinch, the knife-blade. END
BEGIN NOW He shaved warily over his chin. END
BEGIN NOW —He was raving all night about a black panther, Stephen said. END
BEGIN NOW Where is END
BEGIN NOW his guncase? END
BEGIN NOW —A woful lunatic! END
BEGIN NOW Mulligan said. END
BEGIN NOW Were you in a funk? END
BEGIN NOW —I was, Stephen said with energy and growing fear. END
BEGIN NOW Out here in the dark END
BEGIN NOW with a man I don't know raving and moaning to himself about shooting a END
BEGIN NOW black panther. END
BEGIN NOW You saved men from drowning. END
BEGIN NOW I'm not a hero, however. END
BEGIN NOW If END
BEGIN NOW he stays on here I am off. END
BEGIN NOW Buck Mulligan frowned at the lather on his razorblade. END
BEGIN NOW He hopped down END
BEGIN NOW from his perch and began to search his trouser pockets hastily. END
BEGIN NOW —Scutter! END
BEGIN NOW he cried thickly. END
BEGIN NOW He came over to the gunrest and, thrusting a hand into Stephen's upper END
BEGIN NOW pocket, said: END
BEGIN NOW —Lend us a loan of your noserag to wipe my razor. END
BEGIN NOW Stephen suffered him to pull out and hold up on show by its corner a END
BEGIN NOW dirty crumpled handkerchief. END
BEGIN NOW Buck Mulligan wiped the razorblade neatly. END
BEGIN NOW Then, gazing over the handkerchief, he said: END
BEGIN NOW —The bard's noserag! END
BEGIN NOW A new art colour for our Irish poets: snotgreen. END
BEGIN NOW You can almost taste it, can't you? END
BEGIN NOW He mounted to the parapet again and gazed out over Dublin bay, his fair END
BEGIN NOW oakpale hair stirring slightly. END
BEGIN NOW —God! END
BEGIN NOW he said quietly. END
BEGIN NOW Isn't the sea what Algy calls it: a great sweet END
BEGIN NOW mother? END
BEGIN NOW The snotgreen sea. END
BEGIN NOW The scrotumtightening sea. END
BEGIN NOW Epi oinopa ponton. END
BEGIN NOW Ah, Dedalus, the Greeks! END
BEGIN NOW I must teach you. END
BEGIN NOW You must read them in the END
BEGIN NOW original. END
BEGIN NOW Thalatta! END
BEGIN NOW Thalatta! END
BEGIN NOW She is our great sweet mother. END
BEGIN NOW Come and END
BEGIN NOW look. END
BEGIN NOW Stephen stood up and went over to the parapet. END
BEGIN NOW Leaning on it he looked END
BEGIN NOW down on the water and on the mailboat clearing the harbourmouth of END
BEGIN NOW Kingstown. END
BEGIN NOW —Our mighty mother! END
BEGIN NOW Buck Mulligan said. END
BEGIN NOW He turned abruptly his grey searching eyes from the sea to Stephen's END
BEGIN NOW face. END
BEGIN NOW —The aunt thinks you killed your mother, he said. END
BEGIN NOW That's why she won't END
BEGIN NOW let me have anything to do with you. END
BEGIN NOW —Someone killed her, Stephen said gloomily. END
BEGIN NOW —You could have knelt down, damn it, Kinch, when your dying mother asked END
BEGIN NOW you, Buck Mulligan said. END
BEGIN NOW I'm hyperborean as much as you. END
BEGIN NOW But to think of END
BEGIN NOW your mother begging you with her last breath to kneel down and pray for END
BEGIN NOW her. END
BEGIN NOW And you refused. END
BEGIN NOW There is something sinister in you.... END
BEGIN NOW He broke off and lathered again lightly his farther cheek. END
BEGIN NOW A tolerant END
BEGIN NOW smile curled his lips. END
BEGIN NOW —But a lovely mummer! END
BEGIN NOW he murmured to himself. END
BEGIN NOW Kinch, the loveliest END
BEGIN NOW mummer of them all! END
BEGIN NOW He shaved evenly and with care, in silence, seriously. END
BEGIN NOW Stephen, an elbow rested on the jagged granite, leaned his palm against END
BEGIN NOW his brow and gazed at the fraying edge of his shiny black coat-sleeve. END
BEGIN NOW Pain, that was not yet the pain of love, fretted his heart. END
BEGIN NOW Silently, in END
BEGIN NOW a dream she had come to him after her death, her wasted body within its END
BEGIN NOW loose brown graveclothes giving off an odour of wax and rosewood, her END
BEGIN NOW breath, that had bent upon him, mute, reproachful, a faint odour of END
BEGIN NOW wetted ashes. END
BEGIN NOW Across the threadbare cuffedge he saw the sea hailed as a END
BEGIN NOW great sweet mother by the wellfed voice beside him. END
BEGIN NOW The ring of bay and END
BEGIN NOW skyline held a dull green mass of liquid. END
BEGIN NOW A bowl of white china had END
BEGIN NOW stood beside her deathbed holding the green sluggish bile which she had END
BEGIN NOW torn up from her rotting liver by fits of loud groaning vomiting. END
BEGIN NOW Buck Mulligan wiped again his razorblade. END
BEGIN NOW —Ah, poor dogsbody! END
BEGIN NOW he said in a kind voice. END
BEGIN NOW I must give you a shirt and END
BEGIN NOW a few noserags. END
BEGIN NOW How are the secondhand breeks? END
BEGIN NOW —They fit well enough, Stephen answered. END
BEGIN NOW Buck Mulligan attacked the hollow beneath his underlip. END
BEGIN NOW —The mockery of it, he said contentedly. END
BEGIN NOW Secondleg they should be. END
BEGIN NOW God END
BEGIN NOW knows what poxy bowsy left them off. END
BEGIN NOW I have a lovely pair with a hair END
BEGIN NOW stripe, grey. END
BEGIN NOW You'll look spiffing in them. END
BEGIN NOW I'm not joking, Kinch. END
BEGIN NOW You END
BEGIN NOW look damn well when you're dressed. END
BEGIN NOW —Thanks, Stephen said. END
BEGIN NOW I can't wear them if they are grey. END
BEGIN NOW —He can't wear them, Buck Mulligan told his face in the mirror. END
BEGIN NOW Etiquette is etiquette. END
BEGIN NOW He kills his mother but he can't wear grey END
BEGIN NOW trousers. END
BEGIN NOW He folded his razor neatly and with stroking palps of fingers felt the END
BEGIN NOW smooth skin. END
BEGIN NOW Stephen turned his gaze from the sea and to the plump face with its END
BEGIN NOW smokeblue mobile eyes. END
BEGIN NOW —That fellow I was with in the Ship last night, said Buck Mulligan, says END
BEGIN NOW you have g. END
BEGIN NOW p. END
BEGIN NOW i. END
BEGIN NOW He's up in Dottyville with Connolly Norman. END
BEGIN NOW General END
BEGIN NOW paralysis of the insane! END
BEGIN NOW He swept the mirror a half circle in the air to flash the tidings abroad END
BEGIN NOW in sunlight now radiant on the sea. END
BEGIN NOW His curling shaven lips laughed and END
BEGIN NOW the edges of his white glittering teeth. END
BEGIN NOW Laughter seized all his strong END
BEGIN NOW wellknit trunk. END
BEGIN NOW —Look at yourself, he said, you dreadful bard! END
BEGIN NOW Stephen bent forward and peered at the mirror held out to him, cleft by END
BEGIN NOW a crooked crack. END
BEGIN NOW Hair on end. END
BEGIN NOW As he and others see me. END
BEGIN NOW Who chose this END
BEGIN NOW face for me? END
BEGIN NOW This dogsbody to rid of vermin. END
BEGIN NOW It asks me too. END
BEGIN NOW —I pinched it out of the skivvy's room, Buck Mulligan said. END
BEGIN NOW It does her END
BEGIN NOW all right. END
BEGIN NOW The aunt always keeps plainlooking servants for Malachi. END
BEGIN NOW Lead END
BEGIN NOW him not into temptation. END
BEGIN NOW And her name is Ursula. END
BEGIN NOW Laughing again, he brought the mirror away from Stephen's peering eyes. END
BEGIN NOW —The rage of Caliban at not seeing his face in a mirror, he said. END
BEGIN NOW If END
BEGIN NOW Wilde were only alive to see you! END
BEGIN NOW Drawing back and pointing, Stephen said with bitterness: END
BEGIN NOW —It is a symbol of Irish art. END
BEGIN NOW The cracked lookingglass of a servant. END
BEGIN NOW Buck Mulligan suddenly linked his arm in Stephen's and walked with him END
BEGIN NOW round the tower, his razor and mirror clacking in the pocket where he END
BEGIN NOW had thrust them. END
BEGIN NOW —It's not fair to tease you like that, Kinch, is it? END
BEGIN NOW he said kindly. END
BEGIN NOW God END
BEGIN NOW knows you have more spirit than any of them. END
BEGIN NOW Parried again. END
BEGIN NOW He fears the lancet of my art as I fear that of his. END
BEGIN NOW The END
BEGIN NOW cold steel pen. END
BEGIN NOW —Cracked lookingglass of a servant! END
BEGIN NOW Tell that to the oxy chap downstairs END
BEGIN NOW and touch him for a guinea. END
BEGIN NOW He's stinking with money and thinks you're END
BEGIN NOW not a gentleman. END
BEGIN NOW His old fellow made his tin by selling jalap to Zulus END
BEGIN NOW or some bloody swindle or other. END
BEGIN NOW God, Kinch, if you and I could only END
BEGIN NOW work together we might do something for the island. END
BEGIN NOW Hellenise it. END
BEGIN NOW Cranly's arm. END
BEGIN NOW His arm. END
BEGIN NOW —And to think of your having to beg from these swine. END
BEGIN NOW I'm the only one END
BEGIN NOW that knows what you are. END
BEGIN NOW Why don't you trust me more? END
BEGIN NOW What have you up END
BEGIN NOW your nose against me? END
BEGIN NOW Is it Haines? END
BEGIN NOW If he makes any noise here I'll END
BEGIN NOW bring down Seymour and we'll give him a ragging worse than they gave END
BEGIN NOW Clive Kempthorpe. END
BEGIN NOW Young shouts of moneyed voices in Clive Kempthorpe's rooms. END
BEGIN NOW Palefaces: END
BEGIN NOW they hold their ribs with laughter, one clasping another. END
BEGIN NOW O, I shall END
BEGIN NOW expire! END
BEGIN NOW Break the news to her gently, Aubrey! END
BEGIN NOW I shall die! END
BEGIN NOW With slit END
BEGIN NOW ribbons of his shirt whipping the air he hops and hobbles round the END
BEGIN NOW table, with trousers down at heels, chased by Ades of Magdalen with the END
BEGIN NOW tailor's shears. END
BEGIN NOW A scared calf's face gilded with marmalade. END
BEGIN NOW I don't END
BEGIN NOW want to be debagged! END
BEGIN NOW Don't you play the giddy ox with me! END
BEGIN NOW Shouts from the open window startling evening in the quadrangle. END
BEGIN NOW A deaf END
BEGIN NOW gardener, aproned, masked with Matthew Arnold's face, pushes his mower END
BEGIN NOW on the sombre lawn watching narrowly the dancing motes of grasshalms. END
BEGIN NOW To ourselves... END
BEGIN NOW new paganism... END
BEGIN NOW omphalos. END
BEGIN NOW —Let him stay, Stephen said. END
BEGIN NOW There's nothing wrong with him except at END
BEGIN NOW night. END
BEGIN NOW —Then what is it? END
BEGIN NOW Buck Mulligan asked impatiently. END
BEGIN NOW Cough it up. END
BEGIN NOW I'm END
BEGIN NOW quite frank with you. END
BEGIN NOW What have you against me now? END
BEGIN NOW They halted, looking towards the blunt cape of Bray Head that lay on the END
BEGIN NOW water like the snout of a sleeping whale. END
BEGIN NOW Stephen freed his arm quietly. END
BEGIN NOW —Do you wish me to tell you? END
BEGIN NOW he asked. END
BEGIN NOW —Yes, what is it? END
BEGIN NOW Buck Mulligan answered. END
BEGIN NOW I don't remember anything. END
BEGIN NOW He looked in Stephen's face as he spoke. END
BEGIN NOW A light wind passed his brow, END
BEGIN NOW fanning softly his fair uncombed hair and stirring silver points of END
BEGIN NOW anxiety in his eyes. END
BEGIN NOW Stephen, depressed by his own voice, said: END
BEGIN NOW —Do you remember the first day I went to your house after my mother's END
BEGIN NOW death? END
BEGIN NOW Buck Mulligan frowned quickly and said: END
BEGIN NOW —What? END
BEGIN NOW Where? END
BEGIN NOW I can't remember anything. END
BEGIN NOW I remember only ideas and END
BEGIN NOW sensations. END
BEGIN NOW Why? END
BEGIN NOW What happened in the name of God? END
BEGIN NOW —You were making tea, Stephen said, and went across the landing to get END
BEGIN NOW more hot water. END
BEGIN NOW Your mother and some visitor came out of the END
BEGIN NOW drawingroom. END
BEGIN NOW She asked you who was in your room. END
BEGIN NOW —Yes? END
BEGIN NOW Buck Mulligan said. END
BEGIN NOW What did I say? END
BEGIN NOW I forget. END
BEGIN NOW —You said, Stephen answered, O, it's only Dedalus whose mother is END
BEGIN NOW beastly dead. END
BEGIN NOW A flush which made him seem younger and more engaging rose to Buck END
BEGIN NOW Mulligan's cheek. END
BEGIN NOW —Did I say that? END
BEGIN NOW he asked. END
BEGIN NOW Well? END
BEGIN NOW What harm is that? END
BEGIN NOW He shook his constraint from him nervously. END
BEGIN NOW —And what is death, he asked, your mother's or yours or my own? END
BEGIN NOW You saw END
BEGIN NOW only your mother die. END
BEGIN NOW I see them pop off every day in the Mater and END
BEGIN NOW Richmond and cut up into tripes in the dissectingroom. END
BEGIN NOW It's a beastly END
BEGIN NOW thing and nothing else. END
BEGIN NOW It simply doesn't matter. END
BEGIN NOW You wouldn't kneel END
BEGIN NOW down to pray for your mother on her deathbed when she asked you. END
BEGIN NOW Why? END
BEGIN NOW Because you have the cursed jesuit strain in you, only it's injected the END
BEGIN NOW wrong way. END
BEGIN NOW To me it's all a mockery and beastly. END
BEGIN NOW Her cerebral lobes are END
BEGIN NOW not functioning. END
BEGIN NOW She calls the doctor sir Peter Teazle and picks END
BEGIN NOW buttercups off the quilt. END
BEGIN NOW Humour her till it's over. END
BEGIN NOW You crossed her END
BEGIN NOW last wish in death and yet you sulk with me because I don't whinge like END
BEGIN NOW some hired mute from Lalouette's. END
BEGIN NOW Absurd! END
BEGIN NOW I suppose I did say it. END
BEGIN NOW I END
BEGIN NOW didn't mean to offend the memory of your mother. END
BEGIN NOW He had spoken himself into boldness. END
BEGIN NOW Stephen, shielding the gaping END
BEGIN NOW wounds which the words had left in his heart, said very coldly: END
BEGIN NOW —I am not thinking of the offence to my mother. END
BEGIN NOW —Of what then? END
BEGIN NOW Buck Mulligan asked. END
BEGIN NOW —Of the offence to me, Stephen answered. END
BEGIN NOW Buck Mulligan swung round on his heel. END
BEGIN NOW —O, an impossible person! END
BEGIN NOW he exclaimed. END
BEGIN NOW He walked off quickly round the parapet. END
BEGIN NOW Stephen stood at his post, END
BEGIN NOW gazing over the calm sea towards the headland. END
BEGIN NOW Sea and headland now grew END
BEGIN NOW dim. END
BEGIN NOW Pulses were beating in his eyes, veiling their sight, and he felt END
BEGIN NOW the fever of his cheeks. END
BEGIN NOW A voice within the tower called loudly: END
BEGIN NOW —Are you up there, Mulligan? END
BEGIN NOW —I'm coming, Buck Mulligan answered. END
BEGIN NOW He turned towards Stephen and said: END
BEGIN NOW —Look at the sea. END
BEGIN NOW What does it care about offences? END
BEGIN NOW Chuck Loyola, Kinch, END
BEGIN NOW and come on down. END
BEGIN NOW The Sassenach wants his morning rashers. END
BEGIN NOW His head halted again for a moment at the top of the staircase, level END
BEGIN NOW with the roof: END
BEGIN NOW —Don't mope over it all day, he said. END
BEGIN NOW I'm inconsequent. END
BEGIN NOW Give up the END
BEGIN NOW moody brooding. END
BEGIN NOW His head vanished but the drone of his descending voice boomed out of END
BEGIN NOW the stairhead: END
BEGIN NOW And no more turn aside and brood Upon love's bitter mystery For Fergus END
BEGIN NOW rules the brazen cars. END
BEGIN NOW Woodshadows floated silently by through the morning peace from the END
BEGIN NOW stairhead seaward where he gazed. END
BEGIN NOW Inshore and farther out the mirror of END
BEGIN NOW water whitened, spurned by lightshod hurrying feet. END
BEGIN NOW White breast of the END
BEGIN NOW dim sea. END
BEGIN NOW The twining stresses, two by two. END
BEGIN NOW A hand plucking the END
BEGIN NOW harpstrings, merging their twining chords. END
BEGIN NOW Wavewhite wedded words END
BEGIN NOW shimmering on the dim tide. END
BEGIN NOW A cloud began to cover the sun slowly, wholly, shadowing the bay in END
BEGIN NOW deeper green. END
BEGIN NOW It lay beneath him, a bowl of bitter waters. END
BEGIN NOW Fergus' song: END
BEGIN NOW I sang it alone in the house, holding down the long dark chords. END
BEGIN NOW Her END
BEGIN NOW door was open: she wanted to hear my music. END
BEGIN NOW Silent with awe and pity I END
BEGIN NOW went to her bedside. END
BEGIN NOW She was crying in her wretched bed. END
BEGIN NOW For those END
BEGIN NOW words, Stephen: love's bitter mystery. END
BEGIN NOW Where now? END
BEGIN NOW Her secrets: old featherfans, tasselled dancecards, powdered with musk, END
BEGIN NOW a gaud of amber beads in her locked drawer. END
BEGIN NOW A birdcage hung in the sunny END
BEGIN NOW window of her house when she was a girl. END
BEGIN NOW She heard old Royce sing in the END
BEGIN NOW pantomime of Turko the Terrible and laughed with others when he sang: END
BEGIN NOW I am the boy That can enjoy Invisibility. END
BEGIN NOW Phantasmal mirth, folded away: muskperfumed. END
BEGIN NOW And no more turn aside and brood. END
BEGIN NOW Folded away in the memory of nature with her toys. END
BEGIN NOW Memories beset his END
BEGIN NOW brooding brain. END
BEGIN NOW Her glass of water from the kitchen tap when she had END
BEGIN NOW approached the sacrament. END
BEGIN NOW A cored apple, filled with brown sugar, END
BEGIN NOW roasting for her at the hob on a dark autumn evening. END
BEGIN NOW Her shapely END
BEGIN NOW fingernails reddened by the blood of squashed lice from the children's END
BEGIN NOW shirts. END
BEGIN NOW In a dream, silently, she had come to him, her wasted body within its END
BEGIN NOW loose graveclothes giving off an odour of wax and rosewood, her breath, END
BEGIN NOW bent over him with mute secret words, a faint odour of wetted ashes. END
BEGIN NOW Her glazing eyes, staring out of death, to shake and bend my soul. END
BEGIN NOW On me END
BEGIN NOW alone. END
BEGIN NOW The ghostcandle to light her agony. END
BEGIN NOW Ghostly light on the tortured END
BEGIN NOW face. END
BEGIN NOW Her hoarse loud breath rattling in horror, while all prayed on END
BEGIN NOW their knees. END
BEGIN NOW Her eyes on me to strike me down. END
BEGIN NOW Liliata rutilantium te END
BEGIN NOW confessorum turma circumdet: iubilantium te virginum chorus excipiat. END
BEGIN NOW Ghoul! END
BEGIN NOW Chewer of corpses! END
BEGIN NOW No, mother! END
BEGIN NOW Let me be and let me live. END
BEGIN NOW —Kinch ahoy! END
BEGIN NOW Buck Mulligan's voice sang from within the tower. END
BEGIN NOW It came nearer up the END
BEGIN NOW staircase, calling again. END
BEGIN NOW Stephen, still trembling at his soul's cry, END
BEGIN NOW heard warm running sunlight and in the air behind him friendly words. END
BEGIN NOW —Dedalus, come down, like a good mosey. END
BEGIN NOW Breakfast is ready. END
BEGIN NOW Haines is END
BEGIN NOW apologising for waking us last night. END
BEGIN NOW It's all right. END
BEGIN NOW —I'm coming, Stephen said, turning. END
BEGIN NOW —Do, for Jesus' sake, Buck Mulligan said. END
BEGIN NOW For my sake and for all our END
BEGIN NOW sakes. END
BEGIN NOW His head disappeared and reappeared. END
BEGIN NOW —I told him your symbol of Irish art. END
BEGIN NOW He says it's very clever. END
BEGIN NOW Touch END
BEGIN NOW him for a quid, will you? END
BEGIN NOW A guinea, I mean. END
BEGIN NOW —I get paid this morning, Stephen said. END
BEGIN NOW —The school kip? END
BEGIN NOW Buck Mulligan said. END
BEGIN NOW How much? END
BEGIN NOW Four quid? END
BEGIN NOW Lend us one. END
BEGIN NOW —If you want it, Stephen said. END
BEGIN NOW —Four shining sovereigns, Buck Mulligan cried with delight. END
BEGIN NOW We'll have a END
BEGIN NOW glorious drunk to astonish the druidy druids. END
BEGIN NOW Four omnipotent END
BEGIN NOW sovereigns. END
BEGIN NOW He flung up his hands and tramped down the stone stairs, singing out of END
BEGIN NOW tune with a Cockney accent: END
BEGIN NOW O, won't we have a merry time, Drinking whisky, beer and wine! END
BEGIN NOW On END
BEGIN NOW coronation, Coronation day! END
BEGIN NOW O, won't we have a merry time On coronation END
BEGIN NOW day! END
BEGIN NOW Warm sunshine merrying over the sea. END
BEGIN NOW The nickel shavingbowl shone, END
BEGIN NOW forgotten, on the parapet. END
BEGIN NOW Why should I bring it down? END
BEGIN NOW Or leave it there END
BEGIN NOW all day, forgotten friendship? END
BEGIN NOW He went over to it, held it in his hands awhile, feeling its coolness, END
BEGIN NOW smelling the clammy slaver of the lather in which the brush was stuck. END
BEGIN NOW So I carried the boat of incense then at Clongowes. END
BEGIN NOW I am another now and END
BEGIN NOW yet the same. END
BEGIN NOW A servant too. END
BEGIN NOW A server of a servant. END
BEGIN NOW In the gloomy domed livingroom of the tower Buck Mulligan's gowned form END
BEGIN NOW moved briskly to and fro about the hearth, hiding and revealing its END
BEGIN NOW yellow glow. END
BEGIN NOW Two shafts of soft daylight fell across the flagged floor END
BEGIN NOW from the high barbacans: and at the meeting of their rays a cloud of END
BEGIN NOW coalsmoke and fumes of fried grease floated, turning. END
BEGIN NOW —We'll be choked, Buck Mulligan said. END
BEGIN NOW Haines, open that door, will you? END
BEGIN NOW Stephen laid the shavingbowl on the locker. END
BEGIN NOW A tall figure rose from the END
BEGIN NOW hammock where it had been sitting, went to the doorway and pulled open END
BEGIN NOW the inner doors. END
BEGIN NOW —Have you the key? END
BEGIN NOW a voice asked. END
BEGIN NOW —Dedalus has it, Buck Mulligan said. END
BEGIN NOW Janey Mack, I'm choked! END
BEGIN NOW He howled, without looking up from the fire: END
BEGIN NOW —Kinch! END
BEGIN NOW —It's in the lock, Stephen said, coming forward. END
BEGIN NOW The key scraped round harshly twice and, when the heavy door had been END
BEGIN NOW set ajar, welcome light and bright air entered. END
BEGIN NOW Haines stood at the END
BEGIN NOW doorway, looking out. END
BEGIN NOW Stephen haled his upended valise to the table and END
BEGIN NOW sat down to wait. END
BEGIN NOW Buck Mulligan tossed the fry on to the dish beside END
BEGIN NOW him. END
BEGIN NOW Then he carried the dish and a large teapot over to the table, set END
BEGIN NOW them down heavily and sighed with relief. END
BEGIN NOW —I'm melting, he said, as the candle remarked when... END
BEGIN NOW But, hush! END
BEGIN NOW Not a END
BEGIN NOW word more on that subject! END
BEGIN NOW Kinch, wake up! END
BEGIN NOW Bread, butter, honey. END
BEGIN NOW Haines, END
BEGIN NOW come in. END
BEGIN NOW The grub is ready. END
BEGIN NOW Bless us, O Lord, and these thy gifts. END
BEGIN NOW Where's the sugar? END
BEGIN NOW O, jay, there's no milk. END
BEGIN NOW Stephen fetched the loaf and the pot of honey and the buttercooler from END
BEGIN NOW the locker. END
BEGIN NOW Buck Mulligan sat down in a sudden pet. END
BEGIN NOW —What sort of a kip is this? END
BEGIN NOW he said. END
BEGIN NOW I told her to come after eight. END
BEGIN NOW —We can drink it black, Stephen said thirstily. END
BEGIN NOW There's a lemon in the END
BEGIN NOW locker. END
BEGIN NOW —O, damn you and your Paris fads! END
BEGIN NOW Buck Mulligan said. END
BEGIN NOW I want Sandycove END
BEGIN NOW milk. END
BEGIN NOW Haines came in from the doorway and said quietly: END
BEGIN NOW —That woman is coming up with the milk. END
BEGIN NOW —The blessings of God on you! END
BEGIN NOW Buck Mulligan cried, jumping up from his END
BEGIN NOW chair. END
BEGIN NOW Sit down. END
BEGIN NOW Pour out the tea there. END
BEGIN NOW The sugar is in the bag. END
BEGIN NOW Here, END
BEGIN NOW I can't go fumbling at the damned eggs. END
BEGIN NOW He hacked through the fry on the dish and slapped it out on three END
BEGIN NOW plates, saying: END
BEGIN NOW —In nomine Patris et Filii et Spiritus Sancti. END
BEGIN NOW Haines sat down to pour out the tea. END
BEGIN NOW —I'm giving you two lumps each, he said. END
BEGIN NOW But, I say, Mulligan, you do END
BEGIN NOW make strong tea, don't you? END
BEGIN NOW Buck Mulligan, hewing thick slices from the loaf, said in an old woman's END
BEGIN NOW wheedling voice: END
BEGIN NOW —When I makes tea I makes tea, as old mother Grogan said. END
BEGIN NOW And when I END
BEGIN NOW makes water I makes water. END
BEGIN NOW —By Jove, it is tea, Haines said. END
BEGIN NOW Buck Mulligan went on hewing and wheedling: END
BEGIN NOW —So I do, Mrs Cahill, says she. END
BEGIN NOW Begob, ma'am, says Mrs Cahill, God send END
BEGIN NOW you don't make them in the one pot. END
BEGIN NOW He lunged towards his messmates in turn a thick slice of bread, impaled END
BEGIN NOW on his knife. END
BEGIN NOW —That's folk, he said very earnestly, for your book, Haines. END
BEGIN NOW Five lines END
BEGIN NOW of text and ten pages of notes about the folk and the fishgods of END
BEGIN NOW Dundrum. END
BEGIN NOW Printed by the weird sisters in the year of the big wind. END
BEGIN NOW He turned to Stephen and asked in a fine puzzled voice, lifting his END
BEGIN NOW brows: END
BEGIN NOW —Can you recall, brother, is mother Grogan's tea and water pot spoken of END
BEGIN NOW in the Mabinogion or is it in the Upanishads? END
BEGIN NOW —I doubt it, said Stephen gravely. END
BEGIN NOW —Do you now? END
BEGIN NOW Buck Mulligan said in the same tone. END
BEGIN NOW Your reasons, pray? END
BEGIN NOW —I fancy, Stephen said as he ate, it did not exist in or out of the END
BEGIN NOW Mabinogion. END
BEGIN NOW Mother Grogan was, one imagines, a kinswoman of Mary Ann. END
BEGIN NOW Buck Mulligan's face smiled with delight. END
BEGIN NOW —Charming! END
BEGIN NOW he said in a finical sweet voice, showing his white teeth and END
BEGIN NOW blinking his eyes pleasantly. END
BEGIN NOW Do you think she was? END
BEGIN NOW Quite charming! END
BEGIN NOW Then, suddenly overclouding all his features, he growled in a hoarsened END
BEGIN NOW rasping voice as he hewed again vigorously at the loaf: END
BEGIN NOW —For old Mary Ann She doesn't care a damn. END
BEGIN NOW But, hising up her END
BEGIN NOW petticoats... END
BEGIN NOW He crammed his mouth with fry and munched and droned. END
BEGIN NOW The doorway was darkened by an entering form. END
BEGIN NOW —The milk, sir! END
BEGIN NOW —Come in, ma'am, Mulligan said. END
BEGIN NOW Kinch, get the jug. END
BEGIN NOW An old woman came forward and stood by Stephen's elbow. END
BEGIN NOW —That's a lovely morning, sir, she said. END
BEGIN NOW Glory be to God. END
BEGIN NOW —To whom? END
BEGIN NOW Mulligan said, glancing at her. END
BEGIN NOW Ah, to be sure! END
BEGIN NOW Stephen reached back and took the milkjug from the locker. END
BEGIN NOW —The islanders, Mulligan said to Haines casually, speak frequently of END
BEGIN NOW the collector of prepuces. END
BEGIN NOW —How much, sir? END
BEGIN NOW asked the old woman. END
BEGIN NOW —A quart, Stephen said. END
BEGIN NOW He watched her pour into the measure and thence into the jug rich white END
BEGIN NOW milk, not hers. END
BEGIN NOW Old shrunken paps. END
BEGIN NOW She poured again a measureful and a END
BEGIN NOW tilly. END
BEGIN NOW Old and secret she had entered from a morning world, maybe a END
BEGIN NOW messenger. END
BEGIN NOW She praised the goodness of the milk, pouring it out. END
BEGIN NOW Crouching by a patient cow at daybreak in the lush field, a witch on her END
BEGIN NOW toadstool, her wrinkled fingers quick at the squirting dugs. END
BEGIN NOW They lowed END
BEGIN NOW about her whom they knew, dewsilky cattle. END
BEGIN NOW Silk of the kine and poor old END
BEGIN NOW woman, names given her in old times. END
BEGIN NOW A wandering crone, lowly form of an END
BEGIN NOW immortal serving her conqueror and her gay betrayer, their common END
BEGIN NOW cuckquean, a messenger from the secret morning. END
BEGIN NOW To serve or to upbraid, END
BEGIN NOW whether he could not tell: but scorned to beg her favour. END
BEGIN NOW —It is indeed, ma'am, Buck Mulligan said, pouring milk into their cups. END
BEGIN NOW —Taste it, sir, she said. END
BEGIN NOW He drank at her bidding. END
BEGIN NOW —If we could live on good food like that, he said to her somewhat END
BEGIN NOW loudly, we wouldn't have the country full of rotten teeth and rotten END
BEGIN NOW guts. END
BEGIN NOW Living in a bogswamp, eating cheap food and the streets paved with END
BEGIN NOW dust, horsedung and consumptives' spits. END
BEGIN NOW —Are you a medical student, sir? END
BEGIN NOW the old woman asked. END
BEGIN NOW —I am, ma'am, Buck Mulligan answered. END
BEGIN NOW —Look at that now, she said. END
BEGIN NOW Stephen listened in scornful silence. END
BEGIN NOW She bows her old head to a voice END
BEGIN NOW that speaks to her loudly, her bonesetter, her medicineman: me she END
BEGIN NOW slights. END
BEGIN NOW To the voice that will shrive and oil for the grave all there END
BEGIN NOW is of her but her woman's unclean loins, of man's flesh made not in END
BEGIN NOW God's likeness, the serpent's prey. END
BEGIN NOW And to the loud voice that now bids END
BEGIN NOW her be silent with wondering unsteady eyes. END
BEGIN NOW —Do you understand what he says? END
BEGIN NOW Stephen asked her. END
BEGIN NOW —Is it French you are talking, sir? END
BEGIN NOW the old woman said to Haines. END
BEGIN NOW Haines spoke to her again a longer speech, confidently. END
BEGIN NOW —Irish, Buck Mulligan said. END
BEGIN NOW Is there Gaelic on you? END
BEGIN NOW —I thought it was Irish, she said, by the sound of it. END
BEGIN NOW Are you from the END
BEGIN NOW west, sir? END
BEGIN NOW —I am an Englishman, Haines answered. END
BEGIN NOW —He's English, Buck Mulligan said, and he thinks we ought to speak Irish END
BEGIN NOW in Ireland. END
BEGIN NOW —Sure we ought to, the old woman said, and I'm ashamed I don't speak the END
BEGIN NOW language myself. END
BEGIN NOW I'm told it's a grand language by them that knows. END
BEGIN NOW —Grand is no name for it, said Buck Mulligan. END
BEGIN NOW Wonderful entirely. END
BEGIN NOW Fill END
BEGIN NOW us out some more tea, Kinch. END
BEGIN NOW Would you like a cup, ma'am? END
BEGIN NOW —No, thank you, sir, the old woman said, slipping the ring of the END
BEGIN NOW milkcan on her forearm and about to go. END
BEGIN NOW Haines said to her: END
BEGIN NOW —Have you your bill? END
BEGIN NOW We had better pay her, Mulligan, hadn't we? END
BEGIN NOW Stephen filled again the three cups. END
BEGIN NOW —Bill, sir? END
BEGIN NOW she said, halting. END
BEGIN NOW Well, it's seven mornings a pint at END
BEGIN NOW twopence is seven twos is a shilling and twopence over and these three END
BEGIN NOW mornings a quart at fourpence is three quarts is a shilling. END
BEGIN NOW That's a END
BEGIN NOW shilling and one and two is two and two, sir. END
BEGIN NOW Buck Mulligan sighed and, having filled his mouth with a crust thickly END
BEGIN NOW buttered on both sides, stretched forth his legs and began to search his END
BEGIN NOW trouser pockets. END
BEGIN NOW —Pay up and look pleasant, Haines said to him, smiling. END
BEGIN NOW Stephen filled a third cup, a spoonful of tea colouring faintly the END
BEGIN NOW thick rich milk. END
BEGIN NOW Buck Mulligan brought up a florin, twisted it round in END
BEGIN NOW his fingers and cried: END
BEGIN NOW —A miracle! END
BEGIN NOW He passed it along the table towards the old woman, saying: END
BEGIN NOW —Ask nothing more of me, sweet. END
BEGIN NOW All I can give you I give. END
BEGIN NOW Stephen laid the coin in her uneager hand. END
BEGIN NOW —We'll owe twopence, he said. END
BEGIN NOW —Time enough, sir, she said, taking the coin. END
BEGIN NOW Time enough. END
BEGIN NOW Good morning, END
BEGIN NOW sir. END
BEGIN NOW She curtseyed and went out, followed by Buck Mulligan's tender chant: END
BEGIN NOW —Heart of my heart, were it more, More would be laid at your feet. END
BEGIN NOW He turned to Stephen and said: END
BEGIN NOW —Seriously, Dedalus. END
BEGIN NOW I'm stony. END
BEGIN NOW Hurry out to your school kip and bring END
BEGIN NOW us back some money. END
BEGIN NOW Today the bards must drink and junket. END
BEGIN NOW Ireland END
BEGIN NOW expects that every man this day will do his duty. END
BEGIN NOW —That reminds me, Haines said, rising, that I have to visit your END
BEGIN NOW national library today. END
BEGIN NOW —Our swim first, Buck Mulligan said. END
BEGIN NOW He turned to Stephen and asked blandly: END
BEGIN NOW —Is this the day for your monthly wash, Kinch? END
BEGIN NOW Then he said to Haines: END
BEGIN NOW —The unclean bard makes a point of washing once a month. END
BEGIN NOW —All Ireland is washed by the gulfstream, Stephen said as he let honey END
BEGIN NOW trickle over a slice of the loaf. END
BEGIN NOW Haines from the corner where he was knotting easily a scarf about the END
BEGIN NOW loose collar of his tennis shirt spoke: END
BEGIN NOW —I intend to make a collection of your sayings if you will let me. END
BEGIN NOW Speaking to me. END
BEGIN NOW They wash and tub and scrub. END
BEGIN NOW Agenbite of inwit. END
BEGIN NOW Conscience. END
BEGIN NOW Yet here's a spot. END
BEGIN NOW —That one about the cracked lookingglass of a servant being the symbol END
BEGIN NOW of Irish art is deuced good. END
BEGIN NOW Buck Mulligan kicked Stephen's foot under the table and said with warmth END
BEGIN NOW of tone: END
BEGIN NOW —Wait till you hear him on Hamlet, Haines. END
BEGIN NOW —Well, I mean it, Haines said, still speaking to Stephen. END
BEGIN NOW I was just END
BEGIN NOW thinking of it when that poor old creature came in. END
BEGIN NOW —Would I make any money by it? END
BEGIN NOW Stephen asked. END
BEGIN NOW Haines laughed and, as he took his soft grey hat from the holdfast of END
BEGIN NOW the hammock, said: END
BEGIN NOW —I don't know, I'm sure. END
BEGIN NOW He strolled out to the doorway. END
BEGIN NOW Buck Mulligan bent across to Stephen and END
BEGIN NOW said with coarse vigour: END
BEGIN NOW —You put your hoof in it now. END
BEGIN NOW What did you say that for? END
BEGIN NOW —Well? END
BEGIN NOW Stephen said. END
BEGIN NOW The problem is to get money. END
BEGIN NOW From whom? END
BEGIN NOW From the END
BEGIN NOW milkwoman or from him. END
BEGIN NOW It's a toss up, I think. END
BEGIN NOW —I blow him out about you, Buck Mulligan said, and then you come along END
BEGIN NOW with your lousy leer and your gloomy jesuit jibes. END
BEGIN NOW —I see little hope, Stephen said, from her or from him. END
BEGIN NOW Buck Mulligan sighed tragically and laid his hand on Stephen's arm. END
BEGIN NOW —From me, Kinch, he said. END
BEGIN NOW In a suddenly changed tone he added: END
BEGIN NOW —To tell you the God's truth I think you're right. END
BEGIN NOW Damn all else they END
BEGIN NOW are good for. END
BEGIN NOW Why don't you play them as I do? END
BEGIN NOW To hell with them all. END
BEGIN NOW Let us get out of the kip. END
BEGIN NOW He stood up, gravely ungirdled and disrobed himself of his gown, saying END
BEGIN NOW resignedly: END
BEGIN NOW —Mulligan is stripped of his garments. END
BEGIN NOW He emptied his pockets on to the table. END
BEGIN NOW —There's your snotrag, he said. END
BEGIN NOW And putting on his stiff collar and rebellious tie he spoke to them, END
BEGIN NOW chiding them, and to his dangling watchchain. END
BEGIN NOW His hands plunged and END
BEGIN NOW rummaged in his trunk while he called for a clean handkerchief. END
BEGIN NOW God, END
BEGIN NOW we'll simply have to dress the character. END
BEGIN NOW I want puce gloves and green END
BEGIN NOW boots. END
BEGIN NOW Contradiction. END
BEGIN NOW Do I contradict myself? END
BEGIN NOW Very well then, I END
BEGIN NOW contradict myself. END
BEGIN NOW Mercurial Malachi. END
BEGIN NOW A limp black missile flew out of END
BEGIN NOW his talking hands. END
BEGIN NOW —And there's your Latin quarter hat, he said. END
BEGIN NOW Stephen picked it up and put it on. END
BEGIN NOW Haines called to them from the END
BEGIN NOW doorway: END
BEGIN NOW —Are you coming, you fellows? END
BEGIN NOW —I'm ready, Buck Mulligan answered, going towards the door. END
BEGIN NOW Come out, END
BEGIN NOW Kinch. END
BEGIN NOW You have eaten all we left, I suppose. END
BEGIN NOW Resigned he passed out END
BEGIN NOW with grave words and gait, saying, wellnigh with sorrow: END
BEGIN NOW —And going forth he met Butterly. END
BEGIN NOW Stephen, taking his ashplant from its leaningplace, followed them out END
BEGIN NOW and, as they went down the ladder, pulled to the slow iron door and END
BEGIN NOW locked it. END
BEGIN NOW He put the huge key in his inner pocket. END
BEGIN NOW At the foot of the ladder Buck Mulligan asked: END
BEGIN NOW —Did you bring the key? END
BEGIN NOW —I have it, Stephen said, preceding them. END
BEGIN NOW He walked on. END
BEGIN NOW Behind him he heard Buck Mulligan club with his heavy END
BEGIN NOW bathtowel the leader shoots of ferns or grasses. END
BEGIN NOW —Down, sir! END
BEGIN NOW How dare you, sir! END
BEGIN NOW Haines asked: END
BEGIN NOW —Do you pay rent for this tower? END
BEGIN NOW —Twelve quid, Buck Mulligan said. END
BEGIN NOW —To the secretary of state for war, Stephen added over his shoulder. END
BEGIN NOW They halted while Haines surveyed the tower and said at last: END
BEGIN NOW —Rather bleak in wintertime, I should say. END
BEGIN NOW Martello you call it? END
BEGIN NOW —Billy Pitt had them built, Buck Mulligan said, when the French were on END
BEGIN NOW the sea. END
BEGIN NOW But ours is the omphalos. END
BEGIN NOW —What is your idea of Hamlet? END
BEGIN NOW Haines asked Stephen. END
BEGIN NOW —No, no, Buck Mulligan shouted in pain. END
BEGIN NOW I'm not equal to Thomas Aquinas END
BEGIN NOW and the fiftyfive reasons he has made out to prop it up. END
BEGIN NOW Wait till I END
BEGIN NOW have a few pints in me first. END
BEGIN NOW He turned to Stephen, saying, as he pulled down neatly the peaks of his END
BEGIN NOW primrose waistcoat: END
BEGIN NOW —You couldn't manage it under three pints, Kinch, could you? END
BEGIN NOW —It has waited so long, Stephen said listlessly, it can wait longer. END
BEGIN NOW —You pique my curiosity, Haines said amiably. END
BEGIN NOW Is it some paradox? END
BEGIN NOW —Pooh! END
BEGIN NOW Buck Mulligan said. END
BEGIN NOW We have grown out of Wilde and paradoxes. END
BEGIN NOW It's quite simple. END
BEGIN NOW He proves by algebra that Hamlet's grandson is END
BEGIN NOW Shakespeare's grandfather and that he himself is the ghost of his own END
BEGIN NOW father. END
BEGIN NOW —What? END
BEGIN NOW Haines said, beginning to point at Stephen. END
BEGIN NOW He himself? END
BEGIN NOW Buck Mulligan slung his towel stolewise round his neck and, bending in END
BEGIN NOW loose laughter, said to Stephen's ear: END
BEGIN NOW —O, shade of Kinch the elder! END
BEGIN NOW Japhet in search of a father! END
BEGIN NOW —We're always tired in the morning, Stephen said to Haines. END
BEGIN NOW And it is END
BEGIN NOW rather long to tell. END
BEGIN NOW Buck Mulligan, walking forward again, raised his hands. END
BEGIN NOW —The sacred pint alone can unbind the tongue of Dedalus, he said. END
BEGIN NOW —I mean to say, Haines explained to Stephen as they followed, this tower END
BEGIN NOW and these cliffs here remind me somehow of Elsinore. END
BEGIN NOW That beetles o'er END
BEGIN NOW his base into the sea, isn't it? END
BEGIN NOW Buck Mulligan turned suddenly for an instant towards Stephen but did not END
BEGIN NOW speak. END
BEGIN NOW In the bright silent instant Stephen saw his own image in cheap END
BEGIN NOW dusty mourning between their gay attires. END
BEGIN NOW —It's a wonderful tale, Haines said, bringing them to halt again. END
BEGIN NOW Eyes, pale as the sea the wind had freshened, paler, firm and prudent. END
BEGIN NOW The seas' ruler, he gazed southward over the bay, empty save for the END
BEGIN NOW smokeplume of the mailboat vague on the bright skyline and a sail END
BEGIN NOW tacking by the Muglins. END
BEGIN NOW —I read a theological interpretation of it somewhere, he said bemused. END
BEGIN NOW The Father and the Son idea. END
BEGIN NOW The Son striving to be atoned with the END
BEGIN NOW Father. END
BEGIN NOW Buck Mulligan at once put on a blithe broadly smiling face. END
BEGIN NOW He looked at END
BEGIN NOW them, his wellshaped mouth open happily, his eyes, from which he had END
BEGIN NOW suddenly withdrawn all shrewd sense, blinking with mad gaiety. END
BEGIN NOW He moved END
BEGIN NOW a doll's head to and fro, the brims of his Panama hat quivering, and END
BEGIN NOW began to chant in a quiet happy foolish voice: END
BEGIN NOW —I'm the queerest young fellow that ever you heard. END
BEGIN NOW My mother's a jew, END
BEGIN NOW my father's a bird. END
BEGIN NOW With Joseph the joiner I cannot agree. END
BEGIN NOW So here's to END
BEGIN NOW disciples and Calvary. END
BEGIN NOW He held up a forefinger of warning. END
BEGIN NOW —If anyone thinks that I amn't divine He'll get no free drinks when I'm END
BEGIN NOW making the wine But have to drink water and wish it were plain That I END
BEGIN NOW make when the wine becomes water again. END
BEGIN NOW He tugged swiftly at Stephen's ashplant in farewell and, running forward END
BEGIN NOW to a brow of the cliff, fluttered his hands at his sides like fins or END
BEGIN NOW wings of one about to rise in the air, and chanted: END
BEGIN NOW —Goodbye, now, goodbye! END
BEGIN NOW Write down all I said And tell Tom, Dick and END
BEGIN NOW Harry I rose from the dead. END
BEGIN NOW What's bred in the bone cannot fail me to END
BEGIN NOW fly And Olivet's breezy... END
BEGIN NOW Goodbye, now, goodbye! END
BEGIN NOW He capered before them down towards the fortyfoot hole, fluttering his END
BEGIN NOW winglike hands, leaping nimbly, Mercury's hat quivering in the fresh END
BEGIN NOW wind that bore back to them his brief birdsweet cries. END
BEGIN NOW Haines, who had been laughing guardedly, walked on beside Stephen and END
BEGIN NOW said: END
BEGIN NOW —We oughtn't to laugh, I suppose. END
BEGIN NOW He's rather blasphemous. END
BEGIN NOW I'm not a END
BEGIN NOW believer myself, that is to say. END
BEGIN NOW Still his gaiety takes the harm out of END
BEGIN NOW it somehow, doesn't it? END
BEGIN NOW What did he call it? END
BEGIN NOW Joseph the Joiner? END
BEGIN NOW —The ballad of joking Jesus, Stephen answered. END
BEGIN NOW —O, Haines said, you have heard it before? END
BEGIN NOW —Three times a day, after meals, Stephen said drily. END
BEGIN NOW —You're not a believer, are you? END
BEGIN NOW Haines asked. END
BEGIN NOW I mean, a believer in the END
BEGIN NOW narrow sense of the word. END
BEGIN NOW Creation from nothing and miracles and a END
BEGIN NOW personal God. END
BEGIN NOW —There's only one sense of the word, it seems to me, Stephen said. END
BEGIN NOW Haines stopped to take out a smooth silver case in which twinkled a END
BEGIN NOW green stone. END
BEGIN NOW He sprang it open with his thumb and offered it. END
BEGIN NOW —Thank you, Stephen said, taking a cigarette. END
BEGIN NOW Haines helped himself and snapped the case to. END
BEGIN NOW He put it back in his END
BEGIN NOW sidepocket and took from his waistcoatpocket a nickel tinderbox, sprang END
BEGIN NOW it open too, and, having lit his cigarette, held the flaming spunk END
BEGIN NOW towards Stephen in the shell of his hands. END
BEGIN NOW —Yes, of course, he said, as they went on again. END
BEGIN NOW Either you believe or END
BEGIN NOW you don't, isn't it? END
BEGIN NOW Personally I couldn't stomach that idea of a END
BEGIN NOW personal God. END
BEGIN NOW You don't stand for that, I suppose? END
BEGIN NOW —You behold in me, Stephen said with grim displeasure, a horrible END
BEGIN NOW example of free thought. END
BEGIN NOW He walked on, waiting to be spoken to, trailing his ashplant by his END
BEGIN NOW side. END
BEGIN NOW Its ferrule followed lightly on the path, squealing at his heels. END
BEGIN NOW My familiar, after me, calling, Steeeeeeeeeeeephen! END
BEGIN NOW A wavering line END
BEGIN NOW along the path. END
BEGIN NOW They will walk on it tonight, coming here in the dark. END
BEGIN NOW He wants that key. END
BEGIN NOW It is mine. END
BEGIN NOW I paid the rent. END
BEGIN NOW Now I eat his salt END
BEGIN NOW bread. END
BEGIN NOW Give him the key too. END
BEGIN NOW All. END
BEGIN NOW He will ask for it. END
BEGIN NOW That was in his END
BEGIN NOW eyes. END
BEGIN NOW —After all, Haines began... END
BEGIN NOW Stephen turned and saw that the cold gaze which had measured him was not END
BEGIN NOW all unkind. END
BEGIN NOW —After all, I should think you are able to free yourself. END
BEGIN NOW You are your END
BEGIN NOW own master, it seems to me. END
BEGIN NOW —I am a servant of two masters, Stephen said, an English and an Italian. END
BEGIN NOW —Italian? END
BEGIN NOW Haines said. END
BEGIN NOW A crazy queen, old and jealous. END
BEGIN NOW Kneel down before me. END
BEGIN NOW —And a third, Stephen said, there is who wants me for odd jobs. END
BEGIN NOW —Italian? END
BEGIN NOW Haines said again. END
BEGIN NOW What do you mean? END
BEGIN NOW —The imperial British state, Stephen answered, his colour rising, and END
BEGIN NOW the holy Roman catholic and apostolic church. END
BEGIN NOW Haines detached from his underlip some fibres of tobacco before he END
BEGIN NOW spoke. END
BEGIN NOW —I can quite understand that, he said calmly. END
BEGIN NOW An Irishman must think END
BEGIN NOW like that, I daresay. END
BEGIN NOW We feel in England that we have treated you rather END
BEGIN NOW unfairly. END
BEGIN NOW It seems history is to blame. END
BEGIN NOW The proud potent titles clanged over Stephen's memory the triumph of END
BEGIN NOW their brazen bells: et unam sanctam catholicam et apostolicam ecclesiam: END
BEGIN NOW the slow growth and change of rite and dogma like his own rare thoughts, END
BEGIN NOW a chemistry of stars. END
BEGIN NOW Symbol of the apostles in the mass for pope END
BEGIN NOW Marcellus, the voices blended, singing alone loud in affirmation: and END
BEGIN NOW behind their chant the vigilant angel of the church militant disarmed END
BEGIN NOW and menaced her heresiarchs. END
BEGIN NOW A horde of heresies fleeing with mitres END
BEGIN NOW awry: Photius and the brood of mockers of whom Mulligan was one, and END
BEGIN NOW Arius, warring his life long upon the consubstantiality of the Son with END
BEGIN NOW the Father, and Valentine, spurning Christ's terrene body, and the END
BEGIN NOW subtle African heresiarch Sabellius who held that the Father was Himself END
BEGIN NOW His own Son. END
BEGIN NOW Words Mulligan had spoken a moment since in mockery to the END
BEGIN NOW stranger. END
BEGIN NOW Idle mockery. END
BEGIN NOW The void awaits surely all them that weave the END
BEGIN NOW wind: a menace, a disarming and a worsting from those embattled angels END
BEGIN NOW of the church, Michael's host, who defend her ever in the hour of END
BEGIN NOW conflict with their lances and their shields. END
BEGIN NOW Hear, hear! END
BEGIN NOW Prolonged applause. END
BEGIN NOW Zut! END
BEGIN NOW Nom de Dieu! END
BEGIN NOW —Of course I'm a Britisher, Haines's voice said, and I feel as one. END
BEGIN NOW I END
BEGIN NOW don't want to see my country fall into the hands of German jews either. END
BEGIN NOW That's our national problem, I'm afraid, just now. END
BEGIN NOW Two men stood at the verge of the cliff, watching: businessman, boatman. END
BEGIN NOW —She's making for Bullock harbour. END
BEGIN NOW The boatman nodded towards the north of the bay with some disdain. END
BEGIN NOW —There's five fathoms out there, he said. END
BEGIN NOW It'll be swept up that way END
BEGIN NOW when the tide comes in about one. END
BEGIN NOW It's nine days today. END
BEGIN NOW The man that was drowned. END
BEGIN NOW A sail veering about the blank bay waiting for END
BEGIN NOW a swollen bundle to bob up, roll over to the sun a puffy face, END
BEGIN NOW saltwhite. END
BEGIN NOW Here I am. END
BEGIN NOW They followed the winding path down to the creek. END
BEGIN NOW Buck Mulligan stood on END
BEGIN NOW a stone, in shirtsleeves, his unclipped tie rippling over his shoulder. END
BEGIN NOW A young man clinging to a spur of rock near him, moved slowly frogwise END
BEGIN NOW his green legs in the deep jelly of the water. END
BEGIN NOW —Is the brother with you, Malachi? END
BEGIN NOW —Down in Westmeath. END
BEGIN NOW With the Bannons. END
BEGIN NOW —Still there? END
BEGIN NOW I got a card from Bannon. END
BEGIN NOW Says he found a sweet young END
BEGIN NOW thing down there. END
BEGIN NOW Photo girl he calls her. END
BEGIN NOW —Snapshot, eh? END
BEGIN NOW Brief exposure. END
BEGIN NOW Buck Mulligan sat down to unlace his boots. END
BEGIN NOW An elderly man shot up near END
BEGIN NOW the spur of rock a blowing red face. END
BEGIN NOW He scrambled up by the stones, END
BEGIN NOW water glistening on his pate and on its garland of grey hair, water END
BEGIN NOW rilling over his chest and paunch and spilling jets out of his black END
BEGIN NOW sagging loincloth. END
BEGIN NOW Buck Mulligan made way for him to scramble past and, glancing at Haines END
BEGIN NOW and Stephen, crossed himself piously with his thumbnail at brow and lips END
BEGIN NOW and breastbone. END
BEGIN NOW —Seymour's back in town, the young man said, grasping again his spur of END
BEGIN NOW rock. END
BEGIN NOW Chucked medicine and going in for the army. END
BEGIN NOW —Ah, go to God! END
BEGIN NOW Buck Mulligan said. END
BEGIN NOW —Going over next week to stew. END
BEGIN NOW You know that red Carlisle girl, Lily? END
BEGIN NOW —Yes. END
BEGIN NOW —Spooning with him last night on the pier. END
BEGIN NOW The father is rotto with END
BEGIN NOW money. END
BEGIN NOW —Is she up the pole? END
BEGIN NOW —Better ask Seymour that. END
BEGIN NOW —Seymour a bleeding officer! END
BEGIN NOW Buck Mulligan said. END
BEGIN NOW He nodded to himself as he drew off his trousers and stood up, saying END
BEGIN NOW tritely: END
BEGIN NOW —Redheaded women buck like goats. END
BEGIN NOW He broke off in alarm, feeling his side under his flapping shirt. END
BEGIN NOW —My twelfth rib is gone, he cried. END
BEGIN NOW I'm the Ãœbermensch. END
BEGIN NOW Toothless Kinch END
BEGIN NOW and I, the supermen. END
BEGIN NOW He struggled out of his shirt and flung it behind him to where his END
BEGIN NOW clothes lay. END
BEGIN NOW —Are you going in here, Malachi? END
BEGIN NOW —Yes. END
BEGIN NOW Make room in the bed. END
BEGIN NOW The young man shoved himself backward through the water and reached the END
BEGIN NOW middle of the creek in two long clean strokes. END
BEGIN NOW Haines sat down on a END
BEGIN NOW stone, smoking. END
BEGIN NOW —Are you not coming in? END
BEGIN NOW Buck Mulligan asked. END
BEGIN NOW —Later on, Haines said. END
BEGIN NOW Not on my breakfast. END
BEGIN NOW Stephen turned away. END
BEGIN NOW —I'm going, Mulligan, he said. END
BEGIN NOW —Give us that key, Kinch, Buck Mulligan said, to keep my chemise flat. END
BEGIN NOW Stephen handed him the key. END
BEGIN NOW Buck Mulligan laid it across his heaped END
BEGIN NOW clothes. END
BEGIN NOW —And twopence, he said, for a pint. END
BEGIN NOW Throw it there. END
BEGIN NOW Stephen threw two pennies on the soft heap. END
BEGIN NOW Dressing, undressing. END
BEGIN NOW Buck END
BEGIN NOW Mulligan erect, with joined hands before him, said solemnly: END
BEGIN NOW —He who stealeth from the poor lendeth to the Lord. END
BEGIN NOW Thus spake END
BEGIN NOW Zarathustra. END
BEGIN NOW His plump body plunged. END
BEGIN NOW —We'll see you again, Haines said, turning as Stephen walked up the path END
BEGIN NOW and smiling at wild Irish. END
BEGIN NOW Horn of a bull, hoof of a horse, smile of a Saxon. END
BEGIN NOW —The Ship, Buck Mulligan cried. END
BEGIN NOW Half twelve. END
BEGIN NOW —Good, Stephen said. END
BEGIN NOW He walked along the upwardcurving path. END
BEGIN NOW Liliata rutilantium. END
BEGIN NOW Turma circumdet. END
BEGIN NOW Iubilantium te virginum. END
BEGIN NOW The priest's grey nimbus in a niche where he dressed discreetly. END
BEGIN NOW I will END
BEGIN NOW not sleep here tonight. END
BEGIN NOW Home also I cannot go. END
BEGIN NOW A voice, sweettoned and sustained, called to him from the sea. END
BEGIN NOW Turning END
BEGIN NOW the curve he waved his hand. END
BEGIN NOW It called again. END
BEGIN NOW A sleek brown head, a END
BEGIN NOW seal's, far out on the water, round. END
BEGIN NOW Usurper. END
BEGIN NOW [ 2 ] END
BEGIN NOW —You, Cochrane, what city sent for him? END
BEGIN NOW —Tarentum, sir. END
BEGIN NOW —Very good. END
BEGIN NOW Well? END
BEGIN NOW —There was a battle, sir. END
BEGIN NOW —Very good. END
BEGIN NOW Where? END
BEGIN NOW The boy's blank face asked the blank window. END
BEGIN NOW Fabled by the daughters of memory. END
BEGIN NOW And yet it was in some way if not as END
BEGIN NOW memory fabled it. END
BEGIN NOW A phrase, then, of impatience, thud of Blake's wings END
BEGIN NOW of excess. END
BEGIN NOW I hear the ruin of all space, shattered glass and toppling END
BEGIN NOW masonry, and time one livid final flame. END
BEGIN NOW What's left us then? END
BEGIN NOW —I forget the place, sir. END
BEGIN NOW 279 B. END
BEGIN NOW C. END
BEGIN NOW —Asculum, Stephen said, glancing at the name and date in the gorescarred END
BEGIN NOW book. END
BEGIN NOW —Yes, sir. END
BEGIN NOW And he said: Another victory like that and we are done for. END
BEGIN NOW That phrase the world had remembered. END
BEGIN NOW A dull ease of the mind. END
BEGIN NOW From a END
BEGIN NOW hill above a corpsestrewn plain a general speaking to his officers, END
BEGIN NOW leaned upon his spear. END
BEGIN NOW Any general to any officers. END
BEGIN NOW They lend ear. END
BEGIN NOW —You, Armstrong, Stephen said. END
BEGIN NOW What was the end of Pyrrhus? END
BEGIN NOW —End of Pyrrhus, sir? END
BEGIN NOW —I know, sir. END
BEGIN NOW Ask me, sir, Comyn said. END
BEGIN NOW —Wait. END
BEGIN NOW You, Armstrong. END
BEGIN NOW Do you know anything about Pyrrhus? END
BEGIN NOW A bag of figrolls lay snugly in Armstrong's satchel. END
BEGIN NOW He curled them END
BEGIN NOW between his palms at whiles and swallowed them softly. END
BEGIN NOW Crumbs adhered to END
BEGIN NOW the tissue of his lips. END
BEGIN NOW A sweetened boy's breath. END
BEGIN NOW Welloff people, proud END
BEGIN NOW that their eldest son was in the navy. END
BEGIN NOW Vico road, Dalkey. END
BEGIN NOW —Pyrrhus, sir? END
BEGIN NOW Pyrrhus, a pier. END
BEGIN NOW All laughed. END
BEGIN NOW Mirthless high malicious laughter. END
BEGIN NOW Armstrong looked round END
BEGIN NOW at his classmates, silly glee in profile. END
BEGIN NOW In a moment they will laugh END
BEGIN NOW more loudly, aware of my lack of rule and of the fees their papas pay. END
BEGIN NOW —Tell me now, Stephen said, poking the boy's shoulder with the book, END
BEGIN NOW what is a pier. END
BEGIN NOW —A pier, sir, Armstrong said. END
BEGIN NOW A thing out in the water. END
BEGIN NOW A kind of a END
BEGIN NOW bridge. END
BEGIN NOW Kingstown pier, sir. END
BEGIN NOW Some laughed again: mirthless but with meaning. END
BEGIN NOW Two in the back bench END
BEGIN NOW whispered. END
BEGIN NOW Yes. END
BEGIN NOW They knew: had never learned nor ever been innocent. END
BEGIN NOW All. END
BEGIN NOW With envy he watched their faces: Edith, Ethel, Gerty, Lily. END
BEGIN NOW Their END
BEGIN NOW likes: their breaths, too, sweetened with tea and jam, their bracelets END
BEGIN NOW tittering in the struggle. END
BEGIN NOW —Kingstown pier, Stephen said. END
BEGIN NOW Yes, a disappointed bridge. END
BEGIN NOW The words troubled their gaze. END
BEGIN NOW —How, sir? END
BEGIN NOW Comyn asked. END
BEGIN NOW A bridge is across a river. END
BEGIN NOW For Haines's chapbook. END
BEGIN NOW No-one here to hear. END
BEGIN NOW Tonight deftly amid wild END
BEGIN NOW drink and talk, to pierce the polished mail of his mind. END
BEGIN NOW What then? END
BEGIN NOW A END
BEGIN NOW jester at the court of his master, indulged and disesteemed, winning a END
BEGIN NOW clement master's praise. END
BEGIN NOW Why had they chosen all that part? END
BEGIN NOW Not wholly END
BEGIN NOW for the smooth caress. END
BEGIN NOW For them too history was a tale like any other END
BEGIN NOW too often heard, their land a pawnshop. END
BEGIN NOW Had Pyrrhus not fallen by a beldam's hand in Argos or Julius Caesar not END
BEGIN NOW been knifed to death. END
BEGIN NOW They are not to be thought away. END
BEGIN NOW Time has branded END
BEGIN NOW them and fettered they are lodged in the room of the infinite END
BEGIN NOW possibilities they have ousted. END
BEGIN NOW But can those have been possible seeing END
BEGIN NOW that they never were? END
BEGIN NOW Or was that only possible which came to pass? END
BEGIN NOW Weave, weaver of the wind. END
BEGIN NOW —Tell us a story, sir. END
BEGIN NOW —O, do, sir. END
BEGIN NOW A ghoststory. END
BEGIN NOW —Where do you begin in this? END
BEGIN NOW Stephen asked, opening another book. END
BEGIN NOW —Weep no more, Comyn said. END
BEGIN NOW —Go on then, Talbot. END
BEGIN NOW —And the story, sir? END
BEGIN NOW —After, Stephen said. END
BEGIN NOW Go on, Talbot. END
BEGIN NOW A swarthy boy opened a book and propped it nimbly under the breastwork END
BEGIN NOW of his satchel. END
BEGIN NOW He recited jerks of verse with odd glances at the text: END
BEGIN NOW —Weep no more, woful shepherds, weep no more For Lycidas, your sorrow, END
BEGIN NOW is not dead, Sunk though he be beneath the watery floor... END
BEGIN NOW It must be a movement then, an actuality of the possible as possible. END
BEGIN NOW Aristotle's phrase formed itself within the gabbled verses and floated END
BEGIN NOW out into the studious silence of the library of Saint Genevieve where he END
BEGIN NOW had read, sheltered from the sin of Paris, night by night. END
BEGIN NOW By his elbow END
BEGIN NOW a delicate Siamese conned a handbook of strategy. END
BEGIN NOW Fed and feeding brains END
BEGIN NOW about me: under glowlamps, impaled, with faintly beating feelers: and in END
BEGIN NOW my mind's darkness a sloth of the underworld, reluctant, shy of END
BEGIN NOW brightness, shifting her dragon scaly folds. END
BEGIN NOW Thought is the thought of END
BEGIN NOW thought. END
BEGIN NOW Tranquil brightness. END
BEGIN NOW The soul is in a manner all that is: the END
BEGIN NOW soul is the form of forms. END
BEGIN NOW Tranquility sudden, vast, candescent: form of END
BEGIN NOW forms. END
BEGIN NOW Talbot repeated: END
BEGIN NOW —Through the dear might of Him that walked the waves, Through the dear END
BEGIN NOW might... END
BEGIN NOW —Turn over, Stephen said quietly. END
BEGIN NOW I don't see anything. END
BEGIN NOW —What, sir? END
BEGIN NOW Talbot asked simply, bending forward. END
BEGIN NOW His hand turned the page over. END
BEGIN NOW He leaned back and went on again, having END
BEGIN NOW just remembered. END
BEGIN NOW Of him that walked the waves. END
BEGIN NOW Here also over these END
BEGIN NOW craven hearts his shadow lies and on the scoffer's heart and lips and on END
BEGIN NOW mine. END
BEGIN NOW It lies upon their eager faces who offered him a coin of the END
BEGIN NOW tribute. END
BEGIN NOW To Caesar what is Caesar's, to God what is God's. END
BEGIN NOW A long look END
BEGIN NOW from dark eyes, a riddling sentence to be woven and woven on the END
BEGIN NOW church's looms. END
BEGIN NOW Ay. END
BEGIN NOW Riddle me, riddle me, randy ro. END
BEGIN NOW My father gave me seeds to sow. END
BEGIN NOW Talbot slid his closed book into his satchel. END
BEGIN NOW —Have I heard all? END
BEGIN NOW Stephen asked. END
BEGIN NOW —Yes, sir. END
BEGIN NOW Hockey at ten, sir. END
BEGIN NOW —Half day, sir. END
BEGIN NOW Thursday. END
BEGIN NOW —Who can answer a riddle? END
BEGIN NOW Stephen asked. END
BEGIN NOW They bundled their books away, pencils clacking, pages rustling. END
BEGIN NOW Crowding together they strapped and buckled their satchels, all gabbling END
BEGIN NOW gaily: END
BEGIN NOW —A riddle, sir? END
BEGIN NOW Ask me, sir. END
BEGIN NOW —O, ask me, sir. END
BEGIN NOW —A hard one, sir. END
BEGIN NOW —This is the riddle, Stephen said: END
BEGIN NOW The cock crew, The sky was blue: The bells in heaven Were striking END
BEGIN NOW eleven. END
BEGIN NOW 'Tis time for this poor soul To go to heaven. END
BEGIN NOW What is that? END
BEGIN NOW —What, sir? END
BEGIN NOW —Again, sir. END
BEGIN NOW We didn't hear. END
BEGIN NOW Their eyes grew bigger as the lines were repeated. END
BEGIN NOW After a silence END
BEGIN NOW Cochrane said: END
BEGIN NOW —What is it, sir? END
BEGIN NOW We give it up. END
BEGIN NOW Stephen, his throat itching, answered: END
BEGIN NOW —The fox burying his grandmother under a hollybush. END
BEGIN NOW He stood up and gave a shout of nervous laughter to which their cries END
BEGIN NOW echoed dismay. END
BEGIN NOW A stick struck the door and a voice in the corridor called: END
BEGIN NOW —Hockey! END
BEGIN NOW They broke asunder, sidling out of their benches, leaping them. END
BEGIN NOW Quickly END
BEGIN NOW they were gone and from the lumberroom came the rattle of sticks and END
BEGIN NOW clamour of their boots and tongues. END
BEGIN NOW Sargent who alone had lingered came forward slowly, showing an open END
BEGIN NOW copybook. END
BEGIN NOW His tangled hair and scraggy neck gave witness of unreadiness END
BEGIN NOW and through his misty glasses weak eyes looked up pleading. END
BEGIN NOW On his END
BEGIN NOW cheek, dull and bloodless, a soft stain of ink lay, dateshaped, recent END
BEGIN NOW and damp as a snail's bed. END
BEGIN NOW He held out his copybook. END
BEGIN NOW The word Sums was written on the headline. END
BEGIN NOW Beneath were sloping figures and at the foot a crooked signature with END
BEGIN NOW blind loops and a blot. END
BEGIN NOW Cyril Sargent: his name and seal. END
BEGIN NOW —Mr Deasy told me to write them out all again, he said, and show them to END
BEGIN NOW you, sir. END
BEGIN NOW Stephen touched the edges of the book. END
BEGIN NOW Futility. END
BEGIN NOW —Do you understand how to do them now? END
BEGIN NOW he asked. END
BEGIN NOW —Numbers eleven to fifteen, Sargent answered. END
BEGIN NOW Mr Deasy said I was to END
BEGIN NOW copy them off the board, sir. END
BEGIN NOW —Can you do them yourself? END
BEGIN NOW Stephen asked. END
BEGIN NOW —No, sir. END
BEGIN NOW Ugly and futile: lean neck and tangled hair and a stain of ink, a END
BEGIN NOW snail's bed. END
BEGIN NOW Yet someone had loved him, borne him in her arms and in her END
BEGIN NOW heart. END
BEGIN NOW But for her the race of the world would have trampled him END
BEGIN NOW underfoot, a squashed boneless snail. END
BEGIN NOW She had loved his weak watery END
BEGIN NOW blood drained from her own. END
BEGIN NOW Was that then real? END
BEGIN NOW The only true thing in END
BEGIN NOW life? END
BEGIN NOW His mother's prostrate body the fiery Columbanus in holy zeal END
BEGIN NOW bestrode. END
BEGIN NOW She was no more: the trembling skeleton of a twig burnt in the END
BEGIN NOW fire, an odour of rosewood and wetted ashes. END
BEGIN NOW She had saved him from END
BEGIN NOW being trampled underfoot and had gone, scarcely having been. END
BEGIN NOW A poor soul END
BEGIN NOW gone to heaven: and on a heath beneath winking stars a fox, red reek of END
BEGIN NOW rapine in his fur, with merciless bright eyes scraped in the earth, END
BEGIN NOW listened, scraped up the earth, listened, scraped and scraped. END
BEGIN NOW Sitting at his side Stephen solved out the problem. END
BEGIN NOW He proves by algebra END
BEGIN NOW that Shakespeare's ghost is Hamlet's grandfather. END
BEGIN NOW Sargent peered askance END
BEGIN NOW through his slanted glasses. END
BEGIN NOW Hockeysticks rattled in the lumberroom: the END
BEGIN NOW hollow knock of a ball and calls from the field. END
BEGIN NOW Across the page the symbols moved in grave morrice, in the mummery of END
BEGIN NOW their letters, wearing quaint caps of squares and cubes. END
BEGIN NOW Give hands, END
BEGIN NOW traverse, bow to partner: so: imps of fancy of the Moors. END
BEGIN NOW Gone too from END
BEGIN NOW the world, Averroes and Moses Maimonides, dark men in mien and movement, END
BEGIN NOW flashing in their mocking mirrors the obscure soul of the world, a END
BEGIN NOW darkness shining in brightness which brightness could not comprehend. END
BEGIN NOW —Do you understand now? END
BEGIN NOW Can you work the second for yourself? END
BEGIN NOW —Yes, sir. END
BEGIN NOW In long shaky strokes Sargent copied the data. END
BEGIN NOW Waiting always for a word END
BEGIN NOW of help his hand moved faithfully the unsteady symbols, a faint hue of END
BEGIN NOW shame flickering behind his dull skin. END
BEGIN NOW Amor matris: subjective and END
BEGIN NOW objective genitive. END
BEGIN NOW With her weak blood and wheysour milk she had fed END
BEGIN NOW him and hid from sight of others his swaddling bands. END
BEGIN NOW Like him was I, these sloping shoulders, this gracelessness. END
BEGIN NOW My END
BEGIN NOW childhood bends beside me. END
BEGIN NOW Too far for me to lay a hand there once or END
BEGIN NOW lightly. END
BEGIN NOW Mine is far and his secret as our eyes. END
BEGIN NOW Secrets, silent, stony END
BEGIN NOW sit in the dark palaces of both our hearts: secrets weary of their END
BEGIN NOW tyranny: tyrants, willing to be dethroned. END
BEGIN NOW The sum was done. END
BEGIN NOW —It is very simple, Stephen said as he stood up. END
BEGIN NOW —Yes, sir. END
BEGIN NOW Thanks, Sargent answered. END
BEGIN NOW He dried the page with a sheet of thin blottingpaper and carried his END
BEGIN NOW copybook back to his bench. END
BEGIN NOW —You had better get your stick and go out to the others, Stephen said as END
BEGIN NOW he followed towards the door the boy's graceless form. END
BEGIN NOW —Yes, sir. END
BEGIN NOW In the corridor his name was heard, called from the playfield. END
BEGIN NOW —Sargent! END
BEGIN NOW —Run on, Stephen said. END
BEGIN NOW Mr Deasy is calling you. END
BEGIN NOW He stood in the porch and watched the laggard hurry towards the scrappy END
BEGIN NOW field where sharp voices were in strife. END
BEGIN NOW They were sorted in teams and END
BEGIN NOW Mr Deasy came away stepping over wisps of grass with gaitered feet. END
BEGIN NOW When END
BEGIN NOW he had reached the schoolhouse voices again contending called to him. END
BEGIN NOW He END
BEGIN NOW turned his angry white moustache. END
BEGIN NOW —What is it now? END
BEGIN NOW he cried continually without listening. END
BEGIN NOW —Cochrane and Halliday are on the same side, sir, Stephen said. END
BEGIN NOW —Will you wait in my study for a moment, Mr Deasy said, till I restore END
BEGIN NOW order here. END
BEGIN NOW And as he stepped fussily back across the field his old man's voice END
BEGIN NOW cried sternly: END
BEGIN NOW —What is the matter? END
BEGIN NOW What is it now? END
BEGIN NOW Their sharp voices cried about him on all sides: their many forms closed END
BEGIN NOW round him, the garish sunshine bleaching the honey of his illdyed head. END
BEGIN NOW Stale smoky air hung in the study with the smell of drab abraded leather END
BEGIN NOW of its chairs. END
BEGIN NOW As on the first day he bargained with me here. END
BEGIN NOW As it was END
BEGIN NOW in the beginning, is now. END
BEGIN NOW On the sideboard the tray of Stuart coins, END
BEGIN NOW base treasure of a bog: and ever shall be. END
BEGIN NOW And snug in their spooncase END
BEGIN NOW of purple plush, faded, the twelve apostles having preached to all the END
BEGIN NOW gentiles: world without end. END
BEGIN NOW A hasty step over the stone porch and in the corridor. END
BEGIN NOW Blowing out his END
BEGIN NOW rare moustache Mr Deasy halted at the table. END
BEGIN NOW —First, our little financial settlement, he said. END
BEGIN NOW He brought out of his coat a pocketbook bound by a leather thong. END
BEGIN NOW It END
BEGIN NOW slapped open and he took from it two notes, one of joined halves, and END
BEGIN NOW laid them carefully on the table. END
BEGIN NOW —Two, he said, strapping and stowing his pocketbook away. END
BEGIN NOW And now his strongroom for the gold. END
BEGIN NOW Stephen's embarrassed hand moved END
BEGIN NOW over the shells heaped in the cold stone mortar: whelks and money END
BEGIN NOW cowries and leopard shells: and this, whorled as an emir's turban, and END
BEGIN NOW this, the scallop of saint James. END
BEGIN NOW An old pilgrim's hoard, dead treasure, END
BEGIN NOW hollow shells. END
BEGIN NOW A sovereign fell, bright and new, on the soft pile of the tablecloth. END
BEGIN NOW —Three, Mr Deasy said, turning his little savingsbox about in his hand. END
BEGIN NOW These are handy things to have. END
BEGIN NOW See. END
BEGIN NOW This is for sovereigns. END
BEGIN NOW This is for END
BEGIN NOW shillings. END
BEGIN NOW Sixpences, halfcrowns. END
BEGIN NOW And here crowns. END
BEGIN NOW See. END
BEGIN NOW He shot from it two crowns and two shillings. END
BEGIN NOW —Three twelve, he said. END
BEGIN NOW I think you'll find that's right. END
BEGIN NOW —Thank you, sir, Stephen said, gathering the money together with shy END
BEGIN NOW haste and putting it all in a pocket of his trousers. END
BEGIN NOW —No thanks at all, Mr Deasy said. END
BEGIN NOW You have earned it. END
BEGIN NOW Stephen's hand, free again, went back to the hollow shells. END
BEGIN NOW Symbols too END
BEGIN NOW of beauty and of power. END
BEGIN NOW A lump in my pocket: symbols soiled by greed and END
BEGIN NOW misery. END
BEGIN NOW —Don't carry it like that, Mr Deasy said. END
BEGIN NOW You'll pull it out somewhere END
BEGIN NOW and lose it. END
BEGIN NOW You just buy one of these machines. END
BEGIN NOW You'll find them very END
BEGIN NOW handy. END
BEGIN NOW Answer something. END
BEGIN NOW —Mine would be often empty, Stephen said. END
BEGIN NOW The same room and hour, the same wisdom: and I the same. END
BEGIN NOW Three times END
BEGIN NOW now. END
BEGIN NOW Three nooses round me here. END
BEGIN NOW Well? END
BEGIN NOW I can break them in this instant END
BEGIN NOW if I will. END
BEGIN NOW —Because you don't save, Mr Deasy said, pointing his finger. END
BEGIN NOW You don't END
BEGIN NOW know yet what money is. END
BEGIN NOW Money is power. END
BEGIN NOW When you have lived as long as I END
BEGIN NOW have. END
BEGIN NOW I know, I know. END
BEGIN NOW If youth but knew. END
BEGIN NOW But what does Shakespeare say? END
BEGIN NOW Put but money in thy purse. END
BEGIN NOW —Iago, Stephen murmured. END
BEGIN NOW He lifted his gaze from the idle shells to the old man's stare. END
BEGIN NOW —He knew what money was, Mr Deasy said. END
BEGIN NOW He made money. END
BEGIN NOW A poet, yes, but END
BEGIN NOW an Englishman too. END
BEGIN NOW Do you know what is the pride of the English? END
BEGIN NOW Do you END
BEGIN NOW know what is the proudest word you will ever hear from an Englishman's END
BEGIN NOW mouth? END
BEGIN NOW The seas' ruler. END
BEGIN NOW His seacold eyes looked on the empty bay: it seems END
BEGIN NOW history is to blame: on me and on my words, unhating. END
BEGIN NOW —That on his empire, Stephen said, the sun never sets. END
BEGIN NOW —Ba! END
BEGIN NOW Mr Deasy cried. END
BEGIN NOW That's not English. END
BEGIN NOW A French Celt said that. END
BEGIN NOW He END
BEGIN NOW tapped his savingsbox against his thumbnail. END
BEGIN NOW —I will tell you, he said solemnly, what is his proudest boast. END
BEGIN NOW I paid END
BEGIN NOW my way. END
BEGIN NOW Good man, good man. END
BEGIN NOW —I paid my way. END
BEGIN NOW I never borrowed a shilling in my life. END
BEGIN NOW Can you feel END
BEGIN NOW that? END
BEGIN NOW I owe nothing. END
BEGIN NOW Can you? END
BEGIN NOW Mulligan, nine pounds, three pairs of socks, one pair brogues, ties. END
BEGIN NOW Curran, ten guineas. END
BEGIN NOW McCann, one guinea. END
BEGIN NOW Fred Ryan, two shillings. END
BEGIN NOW Temple, two lunches. END
BEGIN NOW Russell, one guinea, Cousins, ten shillings, Bob END
BEGIN NOW Reynolds, half a guinea, Koehler, three guineas, Mrs MacKernan, five END
BEGIN NOW weeks' board. END
BEGIN NOW The lump I have is useless. END
BEGIN NOW —For the moment, no, Stephen answered. END
BEGIN NOW Mr Deasy laughed with rich delight, putting back his savingsbox. END
BEGIN NOW —I knew you couldn't, he said joyously. END
BEGIN NOW But one day you must feel it. END
BEGIN NOW We END
BEGIN NOW are a generous people but we must also be just. END
BEGIN NOW —I fear those big words, Stephen said, which make us so unhappy. END
BEGIN NOW Mr Deasy stared sternly for some moments over the mantelpiece at the END
BEGIN NOW shapely bulk of a man in tartan fillibegs: Albert Edward, prince of END
BEGIN NOW Wales. END
BEGIN NOW —You think me an old fogey and an old tory, his thoughtful voice said. END
BEGIN NOW I END
BEGIN NOW saw three generations since O'Connell's time. END
BEGIN NOW I remember the famine in END
BEGIN NOW '46. END
BEGIN NOW Do you know that the orange lodges agitated for repeal of the union END
BEGIN NOW twenty years before O'Connell did or before the prelates of your END
BEGIN NOW communion denounced him as a demagogue? END
BEGIN NOW You fenians forget some things. END
BEGIN NOW Glorious, pious and immortal memory. END
BEGIN NOW The lodge of Diamond in Armagh the END
BEGIN NOW splendid behung with corpses of papishes. END
BEGIN NOW Hoarse, masked and armed, the END
BEGIN NOW planters' covenant. END
BEGIN NOW The black north and true blue bible. END
BEGIN NOW Croppies lie END
BEGIN NOW down. END
BEGIN NOW Stephen sketched a brief gesture. END
BEGIN NOW —I have rebel blood in me too, Mr Deasy said. END
BEGIN NOW On the spindle side. END
BEGIN NOW But I END
BEGIN NOW am descended from sir John Blackwood who voted for the union. END
BEGIN NOW We are all END
BEGIN NOW Irish, all kings' sons. END
BEGIN NOW —Alas, Stephen said. END
BEGIN NOW —Per vias rectas, Mr Deasy said firmly, was his motto. END
BEGIN NOW He voted for it END
BEGIN NOW and put on his topboots to ride to Dublin from the Ards of Down to do END
BEGIN NOW so. END
BEGIN NOW Lal the ral the ra The rocky road to Dublin. END
BEGIN NOW A gruff squire on horseback with shiny topboots. END
BEGIN NOW Soft day, sir John! END
BEGIN NOW Soft day, your honour!... END
BEGIN NOW Day!... END
BEGIN NOW Day!... END
BEGIN NOW Two topboots jog dangling on END
BEGIN NOW to Dublin. END
BEGIN NOW Lal the ral the ra. END
BEGIN NOW Lal the ral the raddy. END
BEGIN NOW —That reminds me, Mr Deasy said. END
BEGIN NOW You can do me a favour, Mr Dedalus, END
BEGIN NOW with some of your literary friends. END
BEGIN NOW I have a letter here for the press. END
BEGIN NOW Sit down a moment. END
BEGIN NOW I have just to copy the end. END
BEGIN NOW He went to the desk near the window, pulled in his chair twice and read END
BEGIN NOW off some words from the sheet on the drum of his typewriter. END
BEGIN NOW —Sit down. END
BEGIN NOW Excuse me, he said over his shoulder, the dictates of common END
BEGIN NOW sense. END
BEGIN NOW Just a moment. END
BEGIN NOW He peered from under his shaggy brows at the manuscript by his elbow END
BEGIN NOW and, muttering, began to prod the stiff buttons of the keyboard slowly, END
BEGIN NOW sometimes blowing as he screwed up the drum to erase an error. END
BEGIN NOW Stephen seated himself noiselessly before the princely presence. END
BEGIN NOW Framed END
BEGIN NOW around the walls images of vanished horses stood in homage, their meek END
BEGIN NOW heads poised in air: lord Hastings' Repulse, the duke of Westminster's END
BEGIN NOW Shotover, the duke of Beaufort's Ceylon, prix de Paris, 1866. END
BEGIN NOW Elfin END
BEGIN NOW riders sat them, watchful of a sign. END
BEGIN NOW He saw their speeds, backing king's END
BEGIN NOW colours, and shouted with the shouts of vanished crowds. END
BEGIN NOW —Full stop, Mr Deasy bade his keys. END
BEGIN NOW But prompt ventilation of this END
BEGIN NOW allimportant question... END
BEGIN NOW Where Cranly led me to get rich quick, hunting his winners among the END
BEGIN NOW mudsplashed brakes, amid the bawls of bookies on their pitches and reek END
BEGIN NOW of the canteen, over the motley slush. END
BEGIN NOW Even money Fair Rebel. END
BEGIN NOW Ten to one END
BEGIN NOW the field. END
BEGIN NOW Dicers and thimbleriggers we hurried by after the hoofs, the END
