BEGIN NOW vying caps and jackets and past the meatfaced woman, a butcher's dame, END
BEGIN NOW nuzzling thirstily her clove of orange. END
BEGIN NOW Shouts rang shrill from the boys' playfield and a whirring whistle. END
BEGIN NOW Again: a goal. END
BEGIN NOW I am among them, among their battling bodies in a medley, END
BEGIN NOW the joust of life. END
BEGIN NOW You mean that knockkneed mother's darling who seems END
BEGIN NOW to be slightly crawsick? END
BEGIN NOW Jousts. END
BEGIN NOW Time shocked rebounds, shock by shock. END
BEGIN NOW Jousts, slush and uproar of battles, the frozen deathspew of the slain, END
BEGIN NOW a shout of spearspikes baited with men's bloodied guts. END
BEGIN NOW —Now then, Mr Deasy said, rising. END
BEGIN NOW He came to the table, pinning together his sheets. END
BEGIN NOW Stephen stood up. END
BEGIN NOW —I have put the matter into a nutshell, Mr Deasy said. END
BEGIN NOW It's about the END
BEGIN NOW foot and mouth disease. END
BEGIN NOW Just look through it. END
BEGIN NOW There can be no two END
BEGIN NOW opinions on the matter. END
BEGIN NOW May I trespass on your valuable space. END
BEGIN NOW That doctrine of laissez faire END
BEGIN NOW which so often in our history. END
BEGIN NOW Our cattle trade. END
BEGIN NOW The way of all our old END
BEGIN NOW industries. END
BEGIN NOW Liverpool ring which jockeyed the Galway harbour scheme. END
BEGIN NOW European conflagration. END
BEGIN NOW Grain supplies through the narrow waters of the END
BEGIN NOW channel. END
BEGIN NOW The pluterperfect imperturbability of the department of END
BEGIN NOW agriculture. END
BEGIN NOW Pardoned a classical allusion. END
BEGIN NOW Cassandra. END
BEGIN NOW By a woman who END
BEGIN NOW was no better than she should be. END
BEGIN NOW To come to the point at issue. END
BEGIN NOW —I don't mince words, do I? END
BEGIN NOW Mr Deasy asked as Stephen read on. END
BEGIN NOW Foot and mouth disease. END
BEGIN NOW Known as Koch's preparation. END
BEGIN NOW Serum and virus. END
BEGIN NOW Percentage of salted horses. END
BEGIN NOW Rinderpest. END
BEGIN NOW Emperor's horses at MÃ¼rzsteg, END
BEGIN NOW lower Austria. END
BEGIN NOW Veterinary surgeons. END
BEGIN NOW Mr Henry Blackwood Price. END
BEGIN NOW Courteous END
BEGIN NOW offer a fair trial. END
BEGIN NOW Dictates of common sense. END
BEGIN NOW Allimportant question. END
BEGIN NOW In END
BEGIN NOW every sense of the word take the bull by the horns. END
BEGIN NOW Thanking you for the END
BEGIN NOW hospitality of your columns. END
BEGIN NOW —I want that to be printed and read, Mr Deasy said. END
BEGIN NOW You will see at the END
BEGIN NOW next outbreak they will put an embargo on Irish cattle. END
BEGIN NOW And it can be END
BEGIN NOW cured. END
BEGIN NOW It is cured. END
BEGIN NOW My cousin, Blackwood Price, writes to me it is END
BEGIN NOW regularly treated and cured in Austria by cattledoctors there. END
BEGIN NOW They END
BEGIN NOW offer to come over here. END
BEGIN NOW I am trying to work up influence with the END
BEGIN NOW department. END
BEGIN NOW Now I'm going to try publicity. END
BEGIN NOW I am surrounded by END
BEGIN NOW difficulties, by... END
BEGIN NOW intrigues by... END
BEGIN NOW backstairs influence by... END
BEGIN NOW He raised his forefinger and beat the air oldly before his voice spoke. END
BEGIN NOW —Mark my words, Mr Dedalus, he said. END
BEGIN NOW England is in the hands of the END
BEGIN NOW jews. END
BEGIN NOW In all the highest places: her finance, her press. END
BEGIN NOW And they are END
BEGIN NOW the signs of a nation's decay. END
BEGIN NOW Wherever they gather they eat up the END
BEGIN NOW nation's vital strength. END
BEGIN NOW I have seen it coming these years. END
BEGIN NOW As sure as END
BEGIN NOW we are standing here the jew merchants are already at their work of END
BEGIN NOW destruction. END
BEGIN NOW Old England is dying. END
BEGIN NOW He stepped swiftly off, his eyes coming to blue life as they passed a END
BEGIN NOW broad sunbeam. END
BEGIN NOW He faced about and back again. END
BEGIN NOW —Dying, he said again, if not dead by now. END
BEGIN NOW The harlot's cry from street to street Shall weave old England's END
BEGIN NOW windingsheet. END
BEGIN NOW His eyes open wide in vision stared sternly across the sunbeam in which END
BEGIN NOW he halted. END
BEGIN NOW —A merchant, Stephen said, is one who buys cheap and sells dear, jew or END
BEGIN NOW gentile, is he not? END
BEGIN NOW —They sinned against the light, Mr Deasy said gravely. END
BEGIN NOW And you can see END
BEGIN NOW the darkness in their eyes. END
BEGIN NOW And that is why they are wanderers on the END
BEGIN NOW earth to this day. END
BEGIN NOW On the steps of the Paris stock exchange the goldskinned men quoting END
BEGIN NOW prices on their gemmed fingers. END
BEGIN NOW Gabble of geese. END
BEGIN NOW They swarmed loud, END
BEGIN NOW uncouth about the temple, their heads thickplotting under maladroit silk END
BEGIN NOW hats. END
BEGIN NOW Not theirs: these clothes, this speech, these gestures. END
BEGIN NOW Their full END
BEGIN NOW slow eyes belied the words, the gestures eager and unoffending, but knew END
BEGIN NOW the rancours massed about them and knew their zeal was vain. END
BEGIN NOW Vain END
BEGIN NOW patience to heap and hoard. END
BEGIN NOW Time surely would scatter all. END
BEGIN NOW A hoard END
BEGIN NOW heaped by the roadside: plundered and passing on. END
BEGIN NOW Their eyes knew their END
BEGIN NOW years of wandering and, patient, knew the dishonours of their flesh. END
BEGIN NOW —Who has not? END
BEGIN NOW Stephen said. END
BEGIN NOW —What do you mean? END
BEGIN NOW Mr Deasy asked. END
BEGIN NOW He came forward a pace and stood by the table. END
BEGIN NOW His underjaw fell END
BEGIN NOW sideways open uncertainly. END
BEGIN NOW Is this old wisdom? END
BEGIN NOW He waits to hear from me. END
BEGIN NOW —History, Stephen said, is a nightmare from which I am trying to awake. END
BEGIN NOW From the playfield the boys raised a shout. END
BEGIN NOW A whirring whistle: goal. END
BEGIN NOW What if that nightmare gave you a back kick? END
BEGIN NOW —The ways of the Creator are not our ways, Mr Deasy said. END
BEGIN NOW All human END
BEGIN NOW history moves towards one great goal, the manifestation of God. END
BEGIN NOW Stephen jerked his thumb towards the window, saying: END
BEGIN NOW —That is God. END
BEGIN NOW Hooray! END
BEGIN NOW Ay! END
BEGIN NOW Whrrwhee! END
BEGIN NOW —What? END
BEGIN NOW Mr Deasy asked. END

BEGIN NOW Mr Deasy looked down and held for awhile the wings of his nose tweaked END
BEGIN NOW between his fingers. END

BEGIN NOW — II — END
BEGIN NOW [ 4 ] END
BEGIN NOW Mr Leopold Bloom ate with relish the inner organs of beasts and fowls. END
BEGIN NOW He liked thick giblet soup, nutty gizzards, a stuffed roast heart, END
BEGIN NOW liverslices fried with crustcrumbs, fried hencods' roes. END
BEGIN NOW Most of all he END
BEGIN NOW liked grilled mutton kidneys which gave to his palate a fine tang of END
BEGIN NOW faintly scented urine. END
BEGIN NOW Kidneys were in his mind as he moved about the kitchen softly, righting END
BEGIN NOW her breakfast things on the humpy tray. END
BEGIN NOW Gelid light and air were in the END
BEGIN NOW kitchen but out of doors gentle summer morning everywhere. END
BEGIN NOW Made him feel END
BEGIN NOW a bit peckish. END
BEGIN NOW The coals were reddening. END
BEGIN NOW Another slice of bread and butter: three, four: right. END
BEGIN NOW She didn't like END
BEGIN NOW her plate full. END
BEGIN NOW Right. END
BEGIN NOW He turned from the tray, lifted the kettle off END
BEGIN NOW the hob and set it sideways on the fire. END
BEGIN NOW It sat there, dull and squat, END
BEGIN NOW its spout stuck out. END
BEGIN NOW Cup of tea soon. END
BEGIN NOW Good. END
BEGIN NOW Mouth dry. END
BEGIN NOW The cat walked END
BEGIN NOW stiffly round a leg of the table with tail on high. END
BEGIN NOW —Mkgnao! END
BEGIN NOW —O, there you are, Mr Bloom said, turning from the fire. END
BEGIN NOW The cat mewed in answer and stalked again stiffly round a leg of the END
BEGIN NOW table, mewing. END
BEGIN NOW Just how she stalks over my writingtable. END
BEGIN NOW Prr. END
BEGIN NOW Scratch my END
BEGIN NOW head. END
BEGIN NOW Prr. END
BEGIN NOW Mr Bloom watched curiously, kindly the lithe black form. END
BEGIN NOW Clean to see: END
BEGIN NOW the gloss of her sleek hide, the white button under the butt of her END
BEGIN NOW tail, the green flashing eyes. END
BEGIN NOW He bent down to her, his hands on his END
BEGIN NOW knees. END
BEGIN NOW —Milk for the pussens, he said. END
BEGIN NOW —Mrkgnao! END
BEGIN NOW the cat cried. END
BEGIN NOW They call them stupid. END
BEGIN NOW They understand what we say better than we END
BEGIN NOW understand them. END
BEGIN NOW She understands all she wants to. END
BEGIN NOW Vindictive too. END
BEGIN NOW Cruel. END
BEGIN NOW Her nature. END
BEGIN NOW Curious mice never squeal. END
BEGIN NOW Seem to like it. END
BEGIN NOW Wonder END
BEGIN NOW what I look like to her. END
BEGIN NOW Height of a tower? END
BEGIN NOW No, she can jump me. END
BEGIN NOW —Afraid of the chickens she is, he said mockingly. END
BEGIN NOW Afraid of the END
BEGIN NOW chookchooks. END

BEGIN NOW Simon, on Ben Dollard's singing of The Croppy Boy. END

BEGIN NOW ballad, Martin, is the most trenchant rendering I ever heard in the END
BEGIN NOW whole course of my experience. END

BEGIN NOW After life's journey. END

BEGIN NOW —That is where Childs was murdered, he said. END
BEGIN NOW The last house. END

BEGIN NOW A gruesome case. END
BEGIN NOW Seymour Bushe got him off. END
BEGIN NOW Murdered his brother. END

BEGIN NOW That's the maxim of the END
BEGIN NOW law. END
BEGIN NOW Better for ninetynine guilty to escape than for one innocent person END
BEGIN NOW to be wrongfully condemned. END

BEGIN NOW Murderer's ground. END
BEGIN NOW It passed darkly. END
BEGIN NOW Shuttered, tenantless, END
BEGIN NOW unweeded garden. END
BEGIN NOW Whole place gone to hell. END
BEGIN NOW Wrongfully condemned. END
BEGIN NOW Murder. END
BEGIN NOW The murderer's image in the eye of the murdered. END
BEGIN NOW They love reading about END
BEGIN NOW it. END
BEGIN NOW Man's head found in a garden. END
BEGIN NOW Her clothing consisted of. END
BEGIN NOW How she met END
BEGIN NOW her death. END
BEGIN NOW Recent outrage. END
BEGIN NOW The weapon used. END
BEGIN NOW Murderer is still at large. END
BEGIN NOW Clues. END
BEGIN NOW A shoelace. END
BEGIN NOW The body to be exhumed. END
BEGIN NOW Murder will out. END
BEGIN NOW Cramped in this carriage. END
BEGIN NOW She mightn't like me to come that way without END
BEGIN NOW letting her know. END
BEGIN NOW Must be careful about women. END
BEGIN NOW Catch them once with END
BEGIN NOW their pants down. END
BEGIN NOW Never forgive you after. END
BEGIN NOW Fifteen. END
BEGIN NOW The high railings of Prospect rippled past their gaze. END
BEGIN NOW Dark poplars, END
BEGIN NOW rare white forms. END
BEGIN NOW Forms more frequent, white shapes thronged amid the END
BEGIN NOW trees, white forms and fragments streaming by mutely, sustaining vain END
BEGIN NOW gestures on the air. END
BEGIN NOW The felly harshed against the curbstone: stopped. END
BEGIN NOW Martin Cunningham put END
BEGIN NOW out his arm and, wrenching back the handle, shoved the door open with END
BEGIN NOW his knee. END
BEGIN NOW He stepped out. END
BEGIN NOW Mr Power and Mr Dedalus followed. END
BEGIN NOW Change that soap now. END
BEGIN NOW Mr Bloom's hand unbuttoned his hip pocket swiftly END
BEGIN NOW and transferred the paperstuck soap to his inner handkerchief pocket. END
BEGIN NOW He END
BEGIN NOW stepped out of the carriage, replacing the newspaper his other hand END
BEGIN NOW still held. END
BEGIN NOW Paltry funeral: coach and three carriages. END
BEGIN NOW It's all the same. END
BEGIN NOW Pallbearers, gold reins, requiem mass, firing a volley. END
BEGIN NOW Pomp of death. END
BEGIN NOW Beyond the hind carriage a hawker stood by his barrow of cakes and END
BEGIN NOW fruit. END
BEGIN NOW Simnel cakes those are, stuck together: cakes for the dead. END
BEGIN NOW Dogbiscuits. END
BEGIN NOW Who ate them? END
BEGIN NOW Mourners coming out. END
BEGIN NOW He followed his companions. END
BEGIN NOW Mr Kernan and Ned Lambert followed, Hynes END
BEGIN NOW walking after them. END
BEGIN NOW Corny Kelleher stood by the opened hearse and took END
BEGIN NOW out the two wreaths. END
BEGIN NOW He handed one to the boy. END
BEGIN NOW Where is that child's funeral disappeared to? END
BEGIN NOW A team of horses passed from Finglas with toiling plodding tread, END
BEGIN NOW dragging through the funereal silence a creaking waggon on which lay a END
BEGIN NOW granite block. END
BEGIN NOW The waggoner marching at their head saluted. END
BEGIN NOW Coffin now. END
BEGIN NOW Got here before us, dead as he is. END
BEGIN NOW Horse looking round at it END
BEGIN NOW with his plume skeowways. END
BEGIN NOW Dull eye: collar tight on his neck, pressing END
BEGIN NOW on a bloodvessel or something. END
BEGIN NOW Do they know what they cart out here END
BEGIN NOW every day? END
BEGIN NOW Must be twenty or thirty funerals every day. END
BEGIN NOW Then Mount END
BEGIN NOW Jerome for the protestants. END
BEGIN NOW Funerals all over the world everywhere every END
BEGIN NOW minute. END
BEGIN NOW Shovelling them under by the cartload doublequick. END
BEGIN NOW Thousands END
BEGIN NOW every hour. END
BEGIN NOW Too many in the world. END
BEGIN NOW Mourners came out through the gates: woman and a girl. END
BEGIN NOW Leanjawed harpy, END
BEGIN NOW hard woman at a bargain, her bonnet awry. END
BEGIN NOW Girl's face stained with dirt END
BEGIN NOW and tears, holding the woman's arm, looking up at her for a sign to cry. END
BEGIN NOW Fish's face, bloodless and livid. END
BEGIN NOW The mutes shouldered the coffin and bore it in through the gates. END
BEGIN NOW So END
BEGIN NOW much dead weight. END
BEGIN NOW Felt heavier myself stepping out of that bath. END

BEGIN NOW the stiff: then the friends of the stiff. END

BEGIN NOW in-law. END
BEGIN NOW All walked after. END
BEGIN NOW Martin Cunningham whispered: END
BEGIN NOW —I was in mortal agony with you talking of suicide before Bloom. END

BEGIN NOW How so? END

BEGIN NOW Mr Power whispered. END

BEGIN NOW Speaking. END
BEGIN NOW —Was he insured? END
BEGIN NOW Mr Bloom asked. END
BEGIN NOW —I believe so, Mr Kernan answered. END
BEGIN NOW But the policy was heavily mortgaged. END
BEGIN NOW Martin is trying to get the youngster into Artane. END
BEGIN NOW —How many children did he leave? END
BEGIN NOW —Five. END
BEGIN NOW Ned Lambert says he'll try to get one of the girls into Todd's. END
BEGIN NOW —A sad case, Mr Bloom said gently. END
BEGIN NOW Five young children. END
BEGIN NOW —A great blow to the poor wife, Mr Kernan added. END
BEGIN NOW —Indeed yes, Mr Bloom agreed. END
BEGIN NOW Has the laugh at him now. END
BEGIN NOW He looked down at the boots he had blacked and polished. END
BEGIN NOW She had END
BEGIN NOW outlived him. END
BEGIN NOW Lost her husband. END
BEGIN NOW More dead for her than for me. END
BEGIN NOW One must END
BEGIN NOW outlive the other. END
BEGIN NOW Wise men say. END
BEGIN NOW There are more women than men in the END
BEGIN NOW world. END
BEGIN NOW Condole with her. END
BEGIN NOW Your terrible loss. END
BEGIN NOW I hope you'll soon follow END
BEGIN NOW him. END
BEGIN NOW For Hindu widows only. END

BEGIN NOW Him? END
BEGIN NOW No. END

BEGIN NOW knows after. END

BEGIN NOW hearts. END
BEGIN NOW All for a shadow. END

BEGIN NOW It never comes. END

BEGIN NOW Ned Lambert said softly, clasping hands. END

BEGIN NOW Mr Dedalus said in subdued wonder. END

BEGIN NOW hat gently on his left knee and, holding its brim, bent over piously. END
BEGIN NOW A server bearing a brass bucket with something in it came out through a END
BEGIN NOW door. END
BEGIN NOW The whitesmocked priest came after him, tidying his stole with one END
BEGIN NOW hand, balancing with the other a little book against his toad's belly. END
BEGIN NOW Who'll read the book? END
BEGIN NOW I, said the rook. END
BEGIN NOW They halted by the bier and the priest began to read out of his book END
BEGIN NOW with a fluent croak. END
BEGIN NOW Father Coffey. END
BEGIN NOW I knew his name was like a coffin. END
BEGIN NOW Domine-namine. END
BEGIN NOW Bully END
BEGIN NOW about the muzzle he looks. END
BEGIN NOW Bosses the show. END
BEGIN NOW Muscular christian. END
BEGIN NOW Woe END

BEGIN NOW sideways like a sheep in clover Dedalus says he will. END

BEGIN NOW him like a poisoned pup. END
BEGIN NOW Most amusing expressions that man finds. END
BEGIN NOW Hhhn: END
BEGIN NOW burst sideways. END

BEGIN NOW Makes them feel more important to be prayed over in Latin. END
BEGIN NOW Requiem mass. END
BEGIN NOW Crape weepers. END
BEGIN NOW Blackedged notepaper. END
BEGIN NOW Your name on the altarlist. END
BEGIN NOW Chilly END
BEGIN NOW place this. END

BEGIN NOW Eyes of a toad too. END
BEGIN NOW What swells him up that way? END
BEGIN NOW Molly gets swelled after cabbage. END
BEGIN NOW Air of END
BEGIN NOW the place maybe. END
BEGIN NOW Looks full up of bad gas. END

BEGIN NOW bad gas round the place. END
BEGIN NOW Butchers, for instance: they get like raw END

BEGIN NOW Mervyn Browne. END

BEGIN NOW saint Werburgh's lovely old organ hundred and fifty they have to bore a END

BEGIN NOW rushes: blue. END
BEGIN NOW One whiff of that and you're a goner. END
BEGIN NOW My kneecap is hurting me. END
BEGIN NOW Ow. END
BEGIN NOW That's better. END

BEGIN NOW shook it again. END
BEGIN NOW Then he came back and put it back in the bucket. END
BEGIN NOW As you END
BEGIN NOW were before you rested. END
BEGIN NOW It's all written down: he has to do it. END
BEGIN NOW —Et ne nos inducas in tentationem. END
BEGIN NOW The server piped the answers in the treble. END
BEGIN NOW I often thought it would be END
BEGIN NOW better to have boy servants. END
BEGIN NOW Up to fifteen or so. END
BEGIN NOW After that, of course END
BEGIN NOW ... END
BEGIN NOW Holy water that was, I expect. END
BEGIN NOW Shaking sleep out of it. END
BEGIN NOW He must be fed END
BEGIN NOW up with that job, shaking that thing over all the corpses they trot up. END
BEGIN NOW What harm if he could see what he was shaking it over. END
BEGIN NOW Every mortal day END
BEGIN NOW a fresh batch: middleaged men, old women, children, women dead in END
BEGIN NOW childbirth, men with beards, baldheaded businessmen, consumptive girls END
BEGIN NOW with little sparrows' breasts. END
BEGIN NOW All the year round he prayed the same END
BEGIN NOW thing over them all and shook water on top of them: sleep. END

BEGIN NOW now. END
BEGIN NOW —In paradisum. END
BEGIN NOW Said he was going to paradise or is in paradise. END

BEGIN NOW everybody. END

BEGIN NOW I don't want your END

BEGIN NOW They bent their silk hats in concert and Hynes inclined his ear. END
BEGIN NOW The END
BEGIN NOW caretaker hung his thumbs in the loops of his gold watchchain and spoke END
BEGIN NOW in a discreet tone to their vacant smiles. END
BEGIN NOW —They tell the story, he said, that two drunks came out here one foggy END
BEGIN NOW evening to look for the grave of a friend of theirs. END
BEGIN NOW They asked for END
BEGIN NOW Mulcahy from the Coombe and were told where he was buried. END
BEGIN NOW After END
BEGIN NOW traipsing about in the fog they found the grave sure enough. END

BEGIN NOW drunks spelt out the name: Terence Mulcahy. END
BEGIN NOW The other drunk was blinking END
BEGIN NOW up at a statue of Our Saviour the widow had got put up. END

BEGIN NOW He END
BEGIN NOW resumed: END
BEGIN NOW —And, after blinking up at the sacred figure, Not a bloody bit like the END

BEGIN NOW —That's all done with a purpose, Martin Cunningham explained to Hynes. END

BEGIN NOW I know that. END
BEGIN NOW —To cheer a fellow up, Martin Cunningham said. END
BEGIN NOW It's pure END
BEGIN NOW goodheartedness: damn the thing else. END

BEGIN NOW like Keyes's ad: no fear of anyone getting out. END

BEGIN NOW the better of a shave. END
BEGIN NOW Grey sprouting beard. END
BEGIN NOW That's the first sign when END
BEGIN NOW the hairs come out grey. END
BEGIN NOW And temper getting cross. END
BEGIN NOW Silver threads among END
BEGIN NOW the grey. END
BEGIN NOW Fancy being his wife. END

BEGIN NOW might thrill her first. END

BEGIN NOW Women especially are so END
BEGIN NOW touchy. END
BEGIN NOW Tell her a ghost story in bed to make her sleep. END

BEGIN NOW Well, I have. END
BEGIN NOW It was a pitchdark night. END
BEGIN NOW The clock was on END
BEGIN NOW the stroke of twelve. END
BEGIN NOW Still they'd kiss all right if properly keyed up. END
BEGIN NOW Whores in Turkish graveyards. END
BEGIN NOW Learn anything if taken young. END
BEGIN NOW You might END
BEGIN NOW pick up a young widow here. END
BEGIN NOW Men like that. END
BEGIN NOW Love among the tombstones. END
BEGIN NOW Romeo. END
BEGIN NOW Spice of pleasure. END
BEGIN NOW In the midst of death we are in life. END
BEGIN NOW Both END
BEGIN NOW ends meet. END
BEGIN NOW Tantalising for the poor dead. END
BEGIN NOW Smell of grilled beefsteaks to END
BEGIN NOW the starving. END
BEGIN NOW Gnawing their vitals. END
BEGIN NOW Desire to grig people. END
BEGIN NOW Molly wanting END
BEGIN NOW to do it at the window. END
BEGIN NOW Eight children he has anyway. END
BEGIN NOW He has seen a fair share go under in his time, lying around him field END
BEGIN NOW after field. END
BEGIN NOW Holy fields. END
BEGIN NOW More room if they buried them standing. END
BEGIN NOW Sitting or kneeling you couldn't. END
BEGIN NOW Standing? END
BEGIN NOW His head might come up some END
BEGIN NOW day above ground in a landslip with his hand pointing. END
BEGIN NOW All honeycombed END
BEGIN NOW the ground must be: oblong cells. END
BEGIN NOW And very neat he keeps it too: trim END
BEGIN NOW grass and edgings. END
BEGIN NOW His garden Major Gamble calls Mount Jerome. END
BEGIN NOW Well, so END
BEGIN NOW it is. END
BEGIN NOW Ought to be flowers of sleep. END
BEGIN NOW Chinese cemeteries with giant END
BEGIN NOW poppies growing produce the best opium Mastiansky told me. END
BEGIN NOW The Botanic END
BEGIN NOW Gardens are just over there. END
BEGIN NOW It's the blood sinking in the earth gives END
BEGIN NOW new life. END
BEGIN NOW Same idea those jews they said killed the christian boy. END
BEGIN NOW Every END
BEGIN NOW man his price. END
BEGIN NOW Well preserved fat corpse, gentleman, epicure, invaluable END
BEGIN NOW for fruit garden. END

BEGIN NOW By carcass of William Wilkinson, auditor END

BEGIN NOW With END
BEGIN NOW thanks. END
BEGIN NOW I daresay the soil would be quite fat with corpsemanure, bones, flesh, END

BEGIN NOW Charnelhouses. END
BEGIN NOW Dreadful. END
BEGIN NOW Turning green and pink decomposing. END
BEGIN NOW Rot END
BEGIN NOW quick in damp earth. END
BEGIN NOW The lean old ones tougher. END
BEGIN NOW Then a kind of a tallowy END
BEGIN NOW kind of a cheesy. END

BEGIN NOW them. END
BEGIN NOW Then dried up. END
BEGIN NOW Deathmoths. END
BEGIN NOW Of course the cells or whatever they END
BEGIN NOW are go on living. END
BEGIN NOW Changing about. END
BEGIN NOW Live for ever practically. END
BEGIN NOW Nothing to END
BEGIN NOW feed on feed on themselves. END

BEGIN NOW Soil must be simply END
BEGIN NOW swirling with them. END
BEGIN NOW Your head it simply swurls. END
BEGIN NOW Those pretty little END
BEGIN NOW seaside gurls. END
BEGIN NOW He looks cheerful enough over it. END
BEGIN NOW Gives him a sense of END
BEGIN NOW power seeing all the others go under first. END
BEGIN NOW Wonder how he looks at life. END
BEGIN NOW Cracking his jokes too: warms the cockles of his heart. END
BEGIN NOW The one about END
BEGIN NOW the bulletin. END
BEGIN NOW Spurgeon went to heaven 4 a.m. END
BEGIN NOW this morning. END
BEGIN NOW 11 p.m. END
BEGIN NOW (closing time). END
BEGIN NOW Not arrived yet. END
BEGIN NOW Peter. END
BEGIN NOW The dead themselves the men END
BEGIN NOW anyhow would like to hear an odd joke or the women to know what's in END
BEGIN NOW fashion. END
BEGIN NOW A juicy pear or ladies' punch, hot, strong and sweet. END

BEGIN NOW the damp. END

BEGIN NOW Shows the profound knowledge of the human heart. END
BEGIN NOW Daren't joke about the dead for two years at least. END

BEGIN NOW prius. END
BEGIN NOW Go out of mourning first. END
BEGIN NOW Hard to imagine his funeral. END
BEGIN NOW Seems a END
BEGIN NOW sort of a joke. END

BEGIN NOW Gives you second wind. END

BEGIN NOW Let me say one thing. END
BEGIN NOW The finest display of oratory I END
BEGIN NOW ever heard was a speech made by John F Taylor at the college historical END
BEGIN NOW society. END
BEGIN NOW Mr Justice Fitzgibbon, the present lord justice of appeal, had END
BEGIN NOW spoken and the paper under debate was an essay (new for those days), END
BEGIN NOW advocating the revival of the Irish tongue. END
BEGIN NOW He turned towards Myles Crawford and said: END
BEGIN NOW —You know Gerald Fitzgibbon. END
BEGIN NOW Then you can imagine the style of his END
BEGIN NOW discourse. END
BEGIN NOW —He is sitting with Tim Healy, J. END
BEGIN NOW J. END
BEGIN NOW O'Molloy said, rumour has it, on END
BEGIN NOW the Trinity college estates commission. END
BEGIN NOW —He is sitting with a sweet thing, Myles Crawford said, in a child's END
BEGIN NOW frock. END
BEGIN NOW Go on. END
BEGIN NOW Well? END
BEGIN NOW —It was the speech, mark you, the professor said, of a finished orator, END
BEGIN NOW full of courteous haughtiness and pouring in chastened diction I will END
BEGIN NOW not say the vials of his wrath but pouring the proud man's contumely END
BEGIN NOW upon the new movement. END
BEGIN NOW It was then a new movement. END
BEGIN NOW We were weak, END
BEGIN NOW therefore worthless. END
BEGIN NOW He closed his long thin lips an instant but, eager to be on, raised an END
BEGIN NOW outspanned hand to his spectacles and, with trembling thumb and END
BEGIN NOW ringfinger touching lightly the black rims, steadied them to a new END
BEGIN NOW focus. END
BEGIN NOW IMPROMPTU END
BEGIN NOW In ferial tone he addressed J. END
BEGIN NOW J. END
BEGIN NOW O'Molloy: END
BEGIN NOW —Taylor had come there, you must know, from a sickbed. END
BEGIN NOW That he had END
BEGIN NOW prepared his speech I do not believe for there was not even one END
BEGIN NOW shorthandwriter in the hall. END
BEGIN NOW His dark lean face had a growth of shaggy END
BEGIN NOW beard round it. END
BEGIN NOW He wore a loose white silk neckcloth and altogether he END
BEGIN NOW looked (though he was not) a dying man. END
BEGIN NOW His gaze turned at once but slowly from J. END
BEGIN NOW J. END
BEGIN NOW O'Molloy's towards END
BEGIN NOW Stephen's face and then bent at once to the ground, seeking. END
BEGIN NOW His END
BEGIN NOW unglazed linen collar appeared behind his bent head, soiled by his END
BEGIN NOW withering hair. END
BEGIN NOW Still seeking, he said: END
BEGIN NOW —When Fitzgibbon's speech had ended John F Taylor rose to reply. END
BEGIN NOW Briefly, as well as I can bring them to mind, his words were these. END
BEGIN NOW He raised his head firmly. END
BEGIN NOW His eyes bethought themselves once more. END
BEGIN NOW Witless shellfish swam in the gross lenses to and fro, seeking outlet. END
BEGIN NOW He began: END
BEGIN NOW —Mr Chairman, ladies and gentlemen: Great was my admiration in listening END
BEGIN NOW to the remarks addressed to the youth of Ireland a moment since by my END
BEGIN NOW learned friend. END
BEGIN NOW It seemed to me that I had been transported into a END
BEGIN NOW country far away from this country, into an age remote from this age, END
BEGIN NOW that I stood in ancient Egypt and that I was listening to the speech of END
BEGIN NOW some highpriest of that land addressed to the youthful Moses. END
BEGIN NOW His listeners held their cigarettes poised to hear, their smokes END
BEGIN NOW ascending in frail stalks that flowered with his speech. END
BEGIN NOW And let our END
BEGIN NOW crooked smokes. END
BEGIN NOW Noble words coming. END
BEGIN NOW Look out. END
BEGIN NOW Could you try your hand at END
BEGIN NOW it yourself? END
BEGIN NOW —And it seemed to me that I heard the voice of that Egyptian highpriest END
BEGIN NOW raised in a tone of like haughtiness and like pride. END
BEGIN NOW I heard his words END
BEGIN NOW and their meaning was revealed to me. END
BEGIN NOW FROM THE FATHERS END
BEGIN NOW It was revealed to me that those things are good which yet are corrupted END
BEGIN NOW which neither if they were supremely good nor unless they were good END
BEGIN NOW could be corrupted. END
BEGIN NOW Ah, curse you! END
BEGIN NOW That's saint Augustine. END
BEGIN NOW —Why will you jews not accept our culture, our religion and our END
BEGIN NOW language? END
BEGIN NOW You are a tribe of nomad herdsmen: we are a mighty people. END
BEGIN NOW You END
BEGIN NOW have no cities nor no wealth: our cities are hives of humanity and our END
BEGIN NOW galleys, trireme and quadrireme, laden with all manner merchandise END
BEGIN NOW furrow the waters of the known globe. END
BEGIN NOW You have but emerged from END
BEGIN NOW primitive conditions: we have a literature, a priesthood, an agelong END
BEGIN NOW history and a polity. END
BEGIN NOW Nile. END
BEGIN NOW Child, man, effigy. END
BEGIN NOW By the Nilebank the babemaries kneel, cradle of bulrushes: a man supple END
BEGIN NOW in combat: stonehorned, stonebearded, heart of stone. END
BEGIN NOW —You pray to a local and obscure idol: our temples, majestic and END
BEGIN NOW mysterious, are the abodes of Isis and Osiris, of Horus and Ammon Ra. END
BEGIN NOW Yours serfdom, awe and humbleness: ours thunder and the seas. END
BEGIN NOW Israel is END
BEGIN NOW weak and few are her children: Egypt is an host and terrible are her END
BEGIN NOW arms. END
BEGIN NOW Vagrants and daylabourers are you called: the world trembles at END
BEGIN NOW our name. END
BEGIN NOW A dumb belch of hunger cleft his speech. END
BEGIN NOW He lifted his voice above it END
BEGIN NOW boldly: END
BEGIN NOW —But, ladies and gentlemen, had the youthful Moses listened to and END
BEGIN NOW accepted that view of life, had he bowed his head and bowed his will and END
BEGIN NOW bowed his spirit before that arrogant admonition he would never have END
BEGIN NOW brought the chosen people out of their house of bondage, nor followed END
BEGIN NOW the pillar of the cloud by day. END
BEGIN NOW He would never have spoken with the END
BEGIN NOW Eternal amid lightnings on Sinai's mountaintop nor ever have come down END
BEGIN NOW with the light of inspiration shining in his countenance and bearing in END
BEGIN NOW his arms the tables of the law, graven in the language of the outlaw. END
BEGIN NOW He ceased and looked at them, enjoying a silence. END
BEGIN NOW OMINOUS—FOR HIM! END
BEGIN NOW J. END
BEGIN NOW J. END
BEGIN NOW O'Molloy said not without regret: END
BEGIN NOW —And yet he died without having entered the land of promise. END
BEGIN NOW —A sudden—at—the—moment—though—from—lingering—illness—often— END
BEGIN NOW previously—expectorated—demise, Lenehan added. END
BEGIN NOW And with a great future END
BEGIN NOW behind him. END
BEGIN NOW The troop of bare feet was heard rushing along the hallway and pattering END
BEGIN NOW up the staircase. END
BEGIN NOW —That is oratory, the professor said uncontradicted. END
BEGIN NOW Gone with the wind. END
BEGIN NOW Hosts at Mullaghmast and Tara of the kings. END
BEGIN NOW Miles of ears of porches. END
BEGIN NOW The tribune's words, howled and scattered to the four winds. END
BEGIN NOW A people END
BEGIN NOW sheltered within his voice. END
BEGIN NOW Dead noise. END
BEGIN NOW Akasic records of all that ever END
BEGIN NOW anywhere wherever was. END
BEGIN NOW Love and laud him: me no more. END
BEGIN NOW I have money. END
BEGIN NOW —Gentlemen, Stephen said. END
BEGIN NOW As the next motion on the agenda paper may I END
BEGIN NOW suggest that the house do now adjourn? END
BEGIN NOW —You take my breath away. END
BEGIN NOW It is not perchance a French compliment? END
BEGIN NOW Mr END
BEGIN NOW O'Madden Burke asked. END
BEGIN NOW 'Tis the hour, methinks, when the winejug, END
BEGIN NOW metaphorically speaking, is most grateful in Ye ancient hostelry. END
BEGIN NOW —That it be and hereby is resolutely resolved. END
BEGIN NOW All that are in favour END
BEGIN NOW say ay, Lenehan announced. END
BEGIN NOW The contrary no. END
BEGIN NOW I declare it carried. END
BEGIN NOW To END
BEGIN NOW which particular boosing shed?... END
BEGIN NOW My casting vote is: Mooney's! END
BEGIN NOW He led the way, admonishing: END
BEGIN NOW —We will sternly refuse to partake of strong waters, will we not? END
BEGIN NOW Yes, END
BEGIN NOW we will not. END
BEGIN NOW By no manner of means. END

BEGIN NOW umbrella: END
BEGIN NOW —Lay on, Macduff! END
BEGIN NOW —Chip of the old block! END

BEGIN NOW shoulder. END

BEGIN NOW I know. END
BEGIN NOW That'll be all right. END

BEGIN NOW they? END
BEGIN NOW That's all right. END

BEGIN NOW LET US HOPE END
BEGIN NOW J. END
BEGIN NOW J. END

BEGIN NOW Myles, one moment. END

BEGIN NOW DEAR DIRTY DUBLIN END
BEGIN NOW Dubliners. END
BEGIN NOW —Two Dublin vestals, Stephen said, elderly and pious, have lived fifty END
BEGIN NOW and fiftythree years in Fumbally's lane. END
BEGIN NOW —Where is that? END
BEGIN NOW the professor asked. END
BEGIN NOW —Off Blackpitts, Stephen said. END
BEGIN NOW Damp night reeking of hungry dough. END
BEGIN NOW Against the wall. END
BEGIN NOW Face glistering END
BEGIN NOW tallow under her fustian shawl. END
BEGIN NOW Frantic hearts. END
BEGIN NOW Akasic records. END
BEGIN NOW Quicker, END
BEGIN NOW darlint! END

BEGIN NOW Dare it. END
BEGIN NOW Let there be life. END
BEGIN NOW —They want to see the views of Dublin from the top of Nelson's pillar. END
BEGIN NOW They save up three and tenpence in a red tin letterbox moneybox. END
BEGIN NOW They END
BEGIN NOW shake out the threepenny bits and sixpences and coax out the pennies END
BEGIN NOW with the blade of a knife. END
BEGIN NOW Two and three in silver and one and seven in END
BEGIN NOW coppers. END
BEGIN NOW They put on their bonnets and best clothes and take their END
BEGIN NOW umbrellas for fear it may come on to rain. END
BEGIN NOW —Wise virgins, professor MacHugh said. END
BEGIN NOW LIFE ON THE RAW END
BEGIN NOW —They buy one and fourpenceworth of brawn and four slices of panloaf at END
BEGIN NOW the north city diningrooms in Marlborough street from Miss Kate Collins, END
BEGIN NOW proprietress... END
BEGIN NOW They purchase four and twenty ripe plums from a girl at END
BEGIN NOW the foot of Nelson's pillar to take off the thirst of the brawn. END
BEGIN NOW They END
BEGIN NOW give two threepenny bits to the gentleman at the turnstile and begin to END
BEGIN NOW waddle slowly up the winding staircase, grunting, encouraging each END
BEGIN NOW other, afraid of the dark, panting, one asking the other have you the END
BEGIN NOW brawn, praising God and the Blessed Virgin, threatening to come down, END
BEGIN NOW peeping at the airslits. END
BEGIN NOW Glory be to God. END
BEGIN NOW They had no idea it was that END
BEGIN NOW high. END
BEGIN NOW Their names are Anne Kearns and Florence MacCabe. END
BEGIN NOW Anne Kearns has the END
BEGIN NOW lumbago for which she rubs on Lourdes water, given her by a lady who got END
BEGIN NOW a bottleful from a passionist father. END
BEGIN NOW Florence MacCabe takes a crubeen END
BEGIN NOW and a bottle of double X for supper every Saturday. END
BEGIN NOW —Antithesis, the professor said nodding twice. END
BEGIN NOW Vestal virgins. END

BEGIN NOW them. END

BEGIN NOW —What is a ghost? END
BEGIN NOW Stephen said with tingling energy. END
BEGIN NOW One who has faded END
BEGIN NOW into impalpability through death, through absence, through change of END
BEGIN NOW manners. END
BEGIN NOW Elizabethan London lay as far from Stratford as corrupt Paris END

BEGIN NOW A player comes on under the shadow, made up in the END

BEGIN NOW It is the END
BEGIN NOW ghost, the king, a king and no king, and the player is Shakespeare who END
BEGIN NOW has studied Hamlet all the years of his life which were not vanity in END
BEGIN NOW order to play the part of the spectre. END

BEGIN NOW bidding him list. END
BEGIN NOW To a son he speaks, the son of his soul, the prince, END
BEGIN NOW young Hamlet and to the son of his body, Hamnet Shakespeare, who has END
BEGIN NOW died in Stratford that his namesake may live for ever. END
BEGIN NOW Is it possible that that player Shakespeare, a ghost by absence, and in END
BEGIN NOW the vesture of buried Denmark, a ghost by death, speaking his own words END
BEGIN NOW to his own son's name (had Hamnet Shakespeare lived he would have been END
BEGIN NOW prince Hamlet's twin), is it possible, I want to know, or probable that END
BEGIN NOW he did not draw or foresee the logical conclusion of those premises: you END

BEGIN NOW —As we, or mother Dana, weave and unweave our bodies, Stephen said, from END
BEGIN NOW day to day, their molecules shuttled to and fro, so does the artist END
BEGIN NOW weave and unweave his image. END
BEGIN NOW And as the mole on my right breast is where END
BEGIN NOW it was when I was born, though all my body has been woven of new stuff END
BEGIN NOW time after time, so through the ghost of the unquiet father the image of END
BEGIN NOW the unliving son looks forth. END
BEGIN NOW In the intense instant of imagination, END
BEGIN NOW when the mind, Shelley says, is a fading coal, that which I was is that END
BEGIN NOW which I am and that which in possibility I may come to be. END
BEGIN NOW So in the END
BEGIN NOW future, the sister of the past, I may see myself as I sit here now but END
BEGIN NOW by reflection from that which then I shall be. END

BEGIN NOW Beware of what you wish for in youth because you END
BEGIN NOW will get it in middle life. END
BEGIN NOW Why does he send to one who is a buonaroba, END
BEGIN NOW a bay where all men ride, a maid of honour with a scandalous girlhood, a END
BEGIN NOW lordling to woo for him? END
BEGIN NOW He was himself a lord of language and had made END
BEGIN NOW himself a coistrel gentleman and he had written Romeo and Juliet. END
BEGIN NOW Why? END
BEGIN NOW Belief in himself has been untimely killed. END
BEGIN NOW He was overborne in a END
BEGIN NOW cornfield first (ryefield, I should say) and he will never be a victor END
BEGIN NOW in his own eyes after nor play victoriously the game of laugh and lie END
BEGIN NOW down. END
BEGIN NOW Assumed dongiovannism will not save him. END
BEGIN NOW No later undoing will END
BEGIN NOW undo the first undoing. END
BEGIN NOW The tusk of the boar has wounded him there where END
BEGIN NOW love lies ableeding. END
BEGIN NOW If the shrew is worsted yet there remains to her END
BEGIN NOW woman's invisible weapon. END
BEGIN NOW There is, I feel in the words, some goad of END
BEGIN NOW the flesh driving him into a new passion, a darker shadow of the first, END
BEGIN NOW darkening even his own understanding of himself. END
BEGIN NOW A like fate awaits him END
BEGIN NOW and the two rages commingle in a whirlpool. END
BEGIN NOW They list. END
BEGIN NOW And in the porches of their ears I pour. END
BEGIN NOW —The soul has been before stricken mortally, a poison poured in the END
BEGIN NOW porch of a sleeping ear. END
BEGIN NOW But those who are done to death in sleep cannot END
BEGIN NOW know the manner of their quell unless their Creator endow their souls END
BEGIN NOW with that knowledge in the life to come. END
BEGIN NOW The poisoning and the beast END
BEGIN NOW with two backs that urged it King Hamlet's ghost could not know of were END
BEGIN NOW he not endowed with knowledge by his creator. END
BEGIN NOW That is why the speech END
BEGIN NOW (his lean unlovely English) is always turned elsewhere, backward. END
BEGIN NOW Ravisher and ravished, what he would but would not, go with him from END
BEGIN NOW Lucrece's bluecircled ivory globes to Imogen's breast, bare, with its END
BEGIN NOW mole cinquespotted. END
BEGIN NOW He goes back, weary of the creation he has piled up END
BEGIN NOW to hide him from himself, an old dog licking an old sore. END
BEGIN NOW But, because END
BEGIN NOW loss is his gain, he passes on towards eternity in undiminished END
BEGIN NOW personality, untaught by the wisdom he has written or by the laws he has END
BEGIN NOW revealed. END
BEGIN NOW His beaver is up. END
BEGIN NOW He is a ghost, a shadow now, the wind by END
BEGIN NOW Elsinore's rocks or what you will, the sea's voice, a voice heard only END
BEGIN NOW in the heart of him who is the substance of his shadow, the son END
BEGIN NOW consubstantial with the father. END

BEGIN NOW was responded from the doorway. END

BEGIN NOW years he lived in London and, during part of that time, he drew a salary END

BEGIN NOW art, more than the art of feudalism as Walt Whitman called it, is the END

BEGIN NOW He drew Shylock out of his own END
BEGIN NOW long pocket. END
BEGIN NOW The son of a maltjobber and moneylender he was himself a END
BEGIN NOW cornjobber and moneylender, with ten tods of corn hoarded in the famine END
BEGIN NOW riots. END
BEGIN NOW His borrowers are no doubt those divers of worship mentioned by END
BEGIN NOW Chettle Falstaff who reported his uprightness of dealing. END
BEGIN NOW He sued a END
BEGIN NOW fellowplayer for the price of a few bags of malt and exacted his pound END
BEGIN NOW of flesh in interest for every money lent. END
BEGIN NOW How else could Aubrey's END
BEGIN NOW ostler and callboy get rich quick? END
BEGIN NOW All events brought grist to his mill. END

BEGIN NOW histories, sail fullbellied on a tide of Mafeking enthusiasm. END

BEGIN NOW Acushla machree! END
BEGIN NOW It's destroyed we are from this day! END
BEGIN NOW It's destroyed we are surely! END
BEGIN NOW All smiled their smiles. END
BEGIN NOW —Saint Thomas, Stephen smiling said, whose gorbellied works I enjoy END
BEGIN NOW reading in the original, writing of incest from a standpoint different END
BEGIN NOW from that of the new Viennese school Mr Magee spoke of, likens it in his END
BEGIN NOW wise and curious way to an avarice of the emotions. END
BEGIN NOW He means that the END
BEGIN NOW love so given to one near in blood is covetously withheld from some END
BEGIN NOW stranger who, it may be, hungers for it. END
BEGIN NOW Jews, whom christians tax with END
BEGIN NOW avarice, are of all races the most given to intermarriage. END
BEGIN NOW Accusations END
BEGIN NOW are made in anger. END
BEGIN NOW The christian laws which built up the hoards of the END
BEGIN NOW jews (for whom, as for the lollards, storm was shelter) bound their END
BEGIN NOW affections too with hoops of steel. END
BEGIN NOW Whether these be sins or virtues old END
BEGIN NOW Nobodaddy will tell us at doomsday leet. END
BEGIN NOW But a man who holds so tightly END
BEGIN NOW to what he calls his rights over what he calls his debts will hold END
BEGIN NOW tightly also to what he calls his rights over her whom he calls his END
BEGIN NOW wife. END
BEGIN NOW No sir smile neighbour shall covet his ox or his wife or his END

BEGIN NOW —Which will? END
BEGIN NOW gagged sweetly Buck Mulligan. END
BEGIN NOW We are getting mixed. END
BEGIN NOW —The will to live, John Eglinton philosophised, for poor Ann, Will's END
BEGIN NOW widow, is the will to die. END
BEGIN NOW —Requiescat! END
BEGIN NOW Stephen prayed. END
BEGIN NOW What of all the will to do? END
BEGIN NOW It has vanished long ago... END
BEGIN NOW —She lies laid out in stark stiffness in that secondbest bed, the mobled END
BEGIN NOW queen, even though you prove that a bed in those days was as rare as a END
BEGIN NOW motorcar is now and that its carvings were the wonder of seven parishes. END
BEGIN NOW In old age she takes up with gospellers (one stayed with her at New END
BEGIN NOW Place and drank a quart of sack the town council paid for but in which END
BEGIN NOW bed he slept it skills not to ask) and heard she had a soul. END
BEGIN NOW She read or END
BEGIN NOW had read to her his chapbooks preferring them to the Merry Wives and, END

BEGIN NOW Most Devout Souls Sneeze. END
BEGIN NOW Venus has twisted her lips in prayer. END
BEGIN NOW Agenbite END
BEGIN NOW of inwit: remorse of conscience. END
BEGIN NOW It is an age of exhausted whoredom END
BEGIN NOW groping for its god. END
BEGIN NOW —History shows that to be true, inquit Eglintonus Chronolologos. END
BEGIN NOW The END
BEGIN NOW ages succeed one another. END
BEGIN NOW But we have it on high authority that a man's END
BEGIN NOW worst enemies shall be those of his own house and family. END
BEGIN NOW I feel that END
BEGIN NOW Russell is right. END
BEGIN NOW What do we care for his wife or father? END
BEGIN NOW I should say END
BEGIN NOW that only family poets have family lives. END
BEGIN NOW Falstaff was not a family man. END
BEGIN NOW I feel that the fat knight is his supreme creation. END
BEGIN NOW Lean, he lay back. END
BEGIN NOW Shy, deny thy kindred, the unco guid. END
BEGIN NOW Shy, supping END
BEGIN NOW with the godless, he sneaks the cup. END
BEGIN NOW A sire in Ultonian Antrim bade it END
BEGIN NOW him. END
BEGIN NOW Visits him here on quarter days. END
BEGIN NOW Mr Magee, sir, there's a gentleman END
BEGIN NOW to see you. END
BEGIN NOW Me? END
BEGIN NOW Says he's your father, sir. END
BEGIN NOW Give me my Wordsworth. END
BEGIN NOW Enter END
BEGIN NOW Magee Mor Matthew, a rugged rough rugheaded kern, in strossers with a END
BEGIN NOW buttoned codpiece, his nether stocks bemired with clauber of ten END
BEGIN NOW forests, a wand of wilding in his hand. END
BEGIN NOW Your own? END
BEGIN NOW He knows your old fellow. END
BEGIN NOW The widower. END
BEGIN NOW Hurrying to her squalid deathlair from gay Paris on the quayside I END
BEGIN NOW touched his hand. END
BEGIN NOW The voice, new warmth, speaking. END
BEGIN NOW Dr Bob Kenny is END
BEGIN NOW attending her. END
BEGIN NOW The eyes that wish me well. END
BEGIN NOW But do not know me. END
BEGIN NOW —A father, Stephen said, battling against hopelessness, is a necessary END
BEGIN NOW evil. END
BEGIN NOW He wrote the play in the months that followed his father's death. END
BEGIN NOW If you hold that he, a greying man with two marriageable daughters, with END
BEGIN NOW thirtyfive years of life, nel mezzo del cammin di nostra vita, with END
BEGIN NOW fifty of experience, is the beardless undergraduate from Wittenberg then END
BEGIN NOW you must hold that his seventyyear old mother is the lustful queen. END
BEGIN NOW No. END
BEGIN NOW The corpse of John Shakespeare does not walk the night. END
BEGIN NOW From hour to END
BEGIN NOW hour it rots and rots. END
BEGIN NOW He rests, disarmed of fatherhood, having devised END
BEGIN NOW that mystical estate upon his son. END
BEGIN NOW Boccaccio's Calandrino was the first END
BEGIN NOW and last man who felt himself with child. END
BEGIN NOW Fatherhood, in the sense of END
BEGIN NOW conscious begetting, is unknown to man. END
BEGIN NOW It is a mystical estate, an END
BEGIN NOW apostolic succession, from only begetter to only begotten. END
BEGIN NOW On that END
BEGIN NOW mystery and not on the madonna which the cunning Italian intellect flung END
BEGIN NOW to the mob of Europe the church is founded and founded irremovably END
BEGIN NOW because founded, like the world, macro and microcosm, upon the void. END
BEGIN NOW Upon incertitude, upon unlikelihood. END
BEGIN NOW Amor matris, subjective and END
BEGIN NOW objective genitive, may be the only true thing in life. END
BEGIN NOW Paternity may be END
BEGIN NOW a legal fiction. END
BEGIN NOW Who is the father of any son that any son should love END
BEGIN NOW him or he any son? END

BEGIN NOW —They are sundered by a bodily shame so steadfast that the criminal END

BEGIN NOW Sons with mothers, sires with daughters, END

BEGIN NOW unborn mars beauty: born, he brings pain, divides affection, increases END

BEGIN NOW —Why? END
BEGIN NOW Stephen answered himself. END
BEGIN NOW Because the theme of the false or the END
BEGIN NOW usurping or the adulterous brother or all three in one is to END
BEGIN NOW Shakespeare, what the poor are not, always with him. END
BEGIN NOW The note of END
BEGIN NOW banishment, banishment from the heart, banishment from home, sounds END
BEGIN NOW uninterruptedly from The Two Gentlemen of Verona onward till Prospero END
BEGIN NOW breaks his staff, buries it certain fathoms in the earth and drowns his END
BEGIN NOW book. END
BEGIN NOW It doubles itself in the middle of his life, reflects itself in END
BEGIN NOW another, repeats itself, protasis, epitasis, catastasis, catastrophe. END
BEGIN NOW It END
BEGIN NOW repeats itself again when he is near the grave, when his married END
BEGIN NOW daughter Susan, chip of the old block, is accused of adultery. END
BEGIN NOW But it END
BEGIN NOW was the original sin that darkened his understanding, weakened his will END
BEGIN NOW and left in him a strong inclination to evil. END
BEGIN NOW The words are those of my END
BEGIN NOW lords bishops of Maynooth. END
BEGIN NOW An original sin and, like original sin, END
BEGIN NOW committed by another in whose sin he too has sinned. END
BEGIN NOW It is between the END
BEGIN NOW lines of his last written words, it is petrified on his tombstone under END
BEGIN NOW which her four bones are not to be laid. END
BEGIN NOW Age has not withered it. END
BEGIN NOW Beauty END
BEGIN NOW and peace have not done it away. END
BEGIN NOW It is in infinite variety everywhere in END
BEGIN NOW the world he has created, in Much Ado about Nothing, twice in As you END
BEGIN NOW like It, in The Tempest, in Hamlet, in Measure for Measure—and in all END
BEGIN NOW the other plays which I have not read. END

BEGIN NOW Father Conmee crossed to Mountjoy square. END
BEGIN NOW He thought, but not for long, END
BEGIN NOW of soldiers and sailors, whose legs had been shot off by cannonballs, END
BEGIN NOW ending their days in some pauper ward, and of cardinal Wolsey's words: END
BEGIN NOW If I had served my God as I have served my king He would not have END
BEGIN NOW abandoned me in my old days. END
BEGIN NOW He walked by the treeshade of sunnywinking END
BEGIN NOW leaves: and towards him came the wife of Mr David Sheehy M.P. END
BEGIN NOW —Very well, indeed, father. END
BEGIN NOW And you, father? END
BEGIN NOW Father Conmee was wonderfully well indeed. END
BEGIN NOW He would go to Buxton END
BEGIN NOW probably for the waters. END
BEGIN NOW And her boys, were they getting on well at END
BEGIN NOW Belvedere? END
BEGIN NOW Was that so? END
BEGIN NOW Father Conmee was very glad indeed to hear that. END
BEGIN NOW And Mr Sheehy himself? END
BEGIN NOW Still in London. END
BEGIN NOW The house was still sitting, to END
BEGIN NOW be sure it was. END
BEGIN NOW Beautiful weather it was, delightful indeed. END
BEGIN NOW Yes, it was END
BEGIN NOW very probable that Father Bernard Vaughan would come again to preach. END
BEGIN NOW O, END
BEGIN NOW yes: a very great success. END

BEGIN NOW in going. END

BEGIN NOW Moored under the trees of Charleville Mall Father Conmee saw a END

BEGIN NOW straw seated amidships, smoking and staring at a branch of poplar above END
BEGIN NOW him. END
BEGIN NOW It was idyllic: and Father Conmee reflected on the providence of END
BEGIN NOW the Creator who had made turf to be in bogs whence men might dig it out END
BEGIN NOW and bring it to town and hamlet to make fires in the houses of poor END
BEGIN NOW people. END

BEGIN NOW At Newcomen bridge Father Conmee stepped into an outward bound tram for END
BEGIN NOW he disliked to traverse on foot the dingy way past Mud Island. END
BEGIN NOW Father Conmee sat in a corner of the tramcar, a blue ticket tucked with END
BEGIN NOW care in the eye of one plump kid glove, while four shillings, a sixpence END
BEGIN NOW and five pennies chuted from his other plump glovepalm into his purse. END
BEGIN NOW Passing the ivy church he reflected that the ticket inspector usually END
BEGIN NOW made his visit when one had carelessly thrown away the ticket. END
BEGIN NOW The END
BEGIN NOW solemnity of the occupants of the car seemed to Father Conmee excessive END
BEGIN NOW for a journey so short and cheap. END
BEGIN NOW Father Conmee liked cheerful decorum. END
BEGIN NOW It was a peaceful day. END
BEGIN NOW The gentleman with the glasses opposite Father END
BEGIN NOW Conmee had finished explaining and looked down. END
BEGIN NOW His wife, Father Conmee END
BEGIN NOW supposed. END
BEGIN NOW A tiny yawn opened the mouth of the wife of the gentleman with END
BEGIN NOW the glasses. END
BEGIN NOW She raised her small gloved fist, yawned ever so gently, END
BEGIN NOW tiptapping her small gloved fist on her opening mouth and smiled tinily, END
BEGIN NOW sweetly. END
BEGIN NOW Father Conmee perceived her perfume in the car. END
BEGIN NOW He perceived also that END
BEGIN NOW the awkward man at the other side of her was sitting on the edge of the END
BEGIN NOW seat. END

BEGIN NOW At Annesley bridge the tram halted and, when it was about to go, an old END
BEGIN NOW woman rose suddenly from her place to alight. END
BEGIN NOW The conductor pulled the END
BEGIN NOW bellstrap to stay the car for her. END
BEGIN NOW She passed out with her basket and a END
BEGIN NOW marketnet: and Father Conmee saw the conductor help her and net and END
BEGIN NOW basket down: and Father Conmee thought that, as she had nearly passed END
BEGIN NOW the end of the penny fare, she was one of those good souls who had END
BEGIN NOW always to be told twice bless you, my child, that they have been END
BEGIN NOW absolved, pray for me. END
BEGIN NOW But they had so many worries in life, so many END
BEGIN NOW cares, poor creatures. END
BEGIN NOW From the hoardings Mr Eugene Stratton grimaced with thick niggerlips at END
BEGIN NOW Father Conmee. END
BEGIN NOW Father Conmee thought of the souls of black and brown and yellow men and END
BEGIN NOW of his sermon on saint Peter Claver S.J. END
BEGIN NOW and the African mission and of END
BEGIN NOW the propagation of the faith and of the millions of black and brown and END
BEGIN NOW yellow souls that had not received the baptism of water when their last END

BEGIN NOW millions of human souls created by God in His Own likeness to whom the END

BEGIN NOW But they were God's souls, created by END
BEGIN NOW God. END
BEGIN NOW It seemed to Father Conmee a pity that they should all be lost, a END
BEGIN NOW waste, if one might say. END
BEGIN NOW At the Howth road stop Father Conmee alighted, was saluted by the END
BEGIN NOW conductor and saluted in his turn. END
BEGIN NOW The Malahide road was quiet. END
BEGIN NOW It pleased Father Conmee, road and name. END
BEGIN NOW The joybells were ringing in gay Malahide. END
BEGIN NOW Lord Talbot de Malahide, END
BEGIN NOW immediate hereditary lord admiral of Malahide and the seas adjoining. END
BEGIN NOW Then came the call to arms and she was maid, wife and widow in one day. END
BEGIN NOW Those were old worldish days, loyal times in joyous townlands, old times END
BEGIN NOW in the barony. END
BEGIN NOW Father Conmee, walking, thought of his little book Old Times in the END
BEGIN NOW Barony and of the book that might be written about jesuit houses and of END
BEGIN NOW Mary Rochfort, daughter of lord Molesworth, first countess of Belvedere. END
BEGIN NOW A listless lady, no more young, walked alone the shore of lough Ennel, END
BEGIN NOW Mary, first countess of Belvedere, listlessly walking in the evening, END
BEGIN NOW not startled when an otter plunged. END
BEGIN NOW Who could know the truth? END
BEGIN NOW Not the END
BEGIN NOW jealous lord Belvedere and not her confessor if she had not committed END
BEGIN NOW adultery fully, eiaculatio seminis inter vas naturale mulieris, with her END
BEGIN NOW husband's brother? END
BEGIN NOW She would half confess if she had not all sinned as END
BEGIN NOW women did. END
BEGIN NOW Only God knew and she and he, her husband's brother. END
BEGIN NOW Father Conmee thought of that tyrannous incontinence, needed however for END
BEGIN NOW man's race on earth, and of the ways of God which were not our ways. END
BEGIN NOW Don John Conmee walked and moved in times of yore. END
BEGIN NOW He was humane and END
BEGIN NOW honoured there. END
BEGIN NOW He bore in mind secrets confessed and he smiled at END
BEGIN NOW smiling noble faces in a beeswaxed drawingroom, ceiled with full fruit END
BEGIN NOW clusters. END
BEGIN NOW And the hands of a bride and of a bridegroom, noble to noble, END
BEGIN NOW were impalmed by Don John Conmee. END
BEGIN NOW It was a charming day. END

BEGIN NOW duke's lawn. END

BEGIN NOW bared he muttered: END
BEGIN NOW —Coactus volui. END

BEGIN NOW face after the striding form. END

BEGIN NOW says Joe. END

BEGIN NOW garrison church at the corner of Chicken lane—old Troy was just giving END
BEGIN NOW me a wrinkle about him—lifted any God's quantity of tea and sugar to pay END
BEGIN NOW three bob a week said he had a farm in the county Down off a hop-of-my- END
BEGIN NOW thumb by the name of Moses Herzog over there near Heytesbury street. END

BEGIN NOW An old plumber named Geraghty. END
BEGIN NOW I'm END
BEGIN NOW hanging on to his taw now for the past fortnight and I can't get a penny END
BEGIN NOW out of him. END
BEGIN NOW —That the lay you're on now? END
BEGIN NOW says Joe. END
BEGIN NOW —Ay, says I. END
BEGIN NOW How are the mighty fallen! END
BEGIN NOW Collector of bad and doubtful END
BEGIN NOW debts. END
BEGIN NOW But that's the most notorious bloody robber you'd meet in a day's END
BEGIN NOW walk and the face on him all pockmarks would hold a shower of rain. END
BEGIN NOW Tell END
BEGIN NOW him, says he, I dare him, says he, and I doubledare him to send you END
BEGIN NOW round here again or if he does, says he, I'll have him summonsed up END
BEGIN NOW before the court, so I will, for trading without a licence. END
BEGIN NOW And he after END
BEGIN NOW stuffing himself till he's fit to burst. END
BEGIN NOW Jesus, I had to laugh at the END
BEGIN NOW little jewy getting his shirt out. END
BEGIN NOW He drink me my teas. END
BEGIN NOW He eat me my END
BEGIN NOW sugars. END

BEGIN NOW For nonperishable goods bought of Moses Herzog, of 13 Saint Kevin's END
BEGIN NOW parade in the city of Dublin, Wood quay ward, merchant, hereinafter END
BEGIN NOW called the vendor, and sold and delivered to Michael E. END
BEGIN NOW Geraghty, END
BEGIN NOW esquire, of 29 Arbour hill in the city of Dublin, Arran quay ward, END
BEGIN NOW gentleman, hereinafter called the purchaser, videlicet, five pounds END
BEGIN NOW avoirdupois of first choice tea at three shillings and no pence per END
BEGIN NOW pound avoirdupois and three stone avoirdupois of sugar, crushed crystal, END
BEGIN NOW at threepence per pound avoirdupois, the said purchaser debtor to the END
BEGIN NOW said vendor of one pound five shillings and sixpence sterling for value END
BEGIN NOW received which amount shall be paid by said purchaser to said vendor in END
BEGIN NOW weekly instalments every seven calendar days of three shillings and no END
BEGIN NOW pence sterling: and the said nonperishable goods shall not be pawned or END
BEGIN NOW pledged or sold or otherwise alienated by the said purchaser but shall END
BEGIN NOW be and remain and be held to be the sole and exclusive property of the END
BEGIN NOW said vendor to be disposed of at his good will and pleasure until the END
BEGIN NOW said amount shall have been duly paid by the said purchaser to the said END
BEGIN NOW vendor in the manner herein set forth as this day hereby agreed between END
BEGIN NOW the said vendor, his heirs, successors, trustees and assigns of the one END
BEGIN NOW part and the said purchaser, his heirs, successors, trustees and assigns END
BEGIN NOW of the other part. END
BEGIN NOW —Are you a strict t.t.? END
BEGIN NOW says Joe. END
BEGIN NOW —Not taking anything between drinks, says I. END
BEGIN NOW —What about paying our respects to our friend? END
BEGIN NOW says Joe. END
BEGIN NOW —Who? END
BEGIN NOW says I. END
BEGIN NOW Sure, he's out in John of God's off his head, poor man. END
BEGIN NOW —Drinking his own stuff? END
BEGIN NOW says Joe. END
BEGIN NOW —Ay, says I. END
BEGIN NOW Whisky and water on the brain. END
BEGIN NOW —Come around to Barney Kiernan's, says Joe. END
BEGIN NOW I want to see the citizen. END
BEGIN NOW —Barney mavourneen's be it, says I. END
BEGIN NOW Anything strange or wonderful, Joe? END
BEGIN NOW —Not a word, says Joe. END
BEGIN NOW I was up at that meeting in the City Arms. END
BEGIN NOW —-What was that, Joe? END
BEGIN NOW says I. END
BEGIN NOW —Cattle traders, says Joe, about the foot and mouth disease. END
BEGIN NOW I want to END
BEGIN NOW give the citizen the hard word about it. END
BEGIN NOW So we went around by the Linenhall barracks and the back of the END
BEGIN NOW courthouse talking of one thing or another. END
BEGIN NOW Decent fellow Joe when he END
BEGIN NOW has it but sure like that he never has it. END
BEGIN NOW Jesus, I couldn't get over END
BEGIN NOW that bloody foxy Geraghty, the daylight robber. END
BEGIN NOW For trading without a END
BEGIN NOW licence, says he. END
BEGIN NOW In Inisfail the fair there lies a land, the land of holy Michan. END
BEGIN NOW There END
BEGIN NOW rises a watchtower beheld of men afar. END
BEGIN NOW There sleep the mighty dead as in END
BEGIN NOW life they slept, warriors and princes of high renown. END
BEGIN NOW A pleasant land it END
BEGIN NOW is in sooth of murmuring waters, fishful streams where sport the END
BEGIN NOW gurnard, the plaice, the roach, the halibut, the gibbed haddock, the END
BEGIN NOW grilse, the dab, the brill, the flounder, the pollock, the mixed coarse END
BEGIN NOW fish generally and other denizens of the aqueous kingdom too numerous to END
BEGIN NOW be enumerated. END
BEGIN NOW In the mild breezes of the west and of the east the lofty END
BEGIN NOW trees wave in different directions their firstclass foliage, the wafty END
BEGIN NOW sycamore, the Lebanonian cedar, the exalted planetree, the eugenic END
BEGIN NOW eucalyptus and other ornaments of the arboreal world with which that END
BEGIN NOW region is thoroughly well supplied. END
BEGIN NOW Lovely maidens sit in close END
BEGIN NOW proximity to the roots of the lovely trees singing the most lovely songs END
BEGIN NOW while they play with all kinds of lovely objects as for example golden END
BEGIN NOW ingots, silvery fishes, crans of herrings, drafts of eels, codlings, END
BEGIN NOW creels of fingerlings, purple seagems and playful insects. END
BEGIN NOW And heroes END
BEGIN NOW voyage from afar to woo them, from Eblana to Slievemargy, the peerless END
BEGIN NOW princes of unfettered Munster and of Connacht the just and of smooth END
BEGIN NOW sleek Leinster and of Cruahan's land and of Armagh the splendid and of END
BEGIN NOW the noble district of Boyle, princes, the sons of kings. END
BEGIN NOW And there rises a shining palace whose crystal glittering roof is seen END
BEGIN NOW by mariners who traverse the extensive sea in barks built expressly for END
BEGIN NOW that purpose, and thither come all herds and fatlings and firstfruits of END
BEGIN NOW that land for O'Connell Fitzsimon takes toll of them, a chieftain END
BEGIN NOW descended from chieftains. END
BEGIN NOW Thither the extremely large wains bring END
BEGIN NOW foison of the fields, flaskets of cauliflowers, floats of spinach, END
BEGIN NOW pineapple chunks, Rangoon beans, strikes of tomatoes, drums of figs, END
BEGIN NOW drills of Swedes, spherical potatoes and tallies of iridescent kale, END
BEGIN NOW York and Savoy, and trays of onions, pearls of the earth, and punnets of END
BEGIN NOW mushrooms and custard marrows and fat vetches and bere and rape and red END
BEGIN NOW green yellow brown russet sweet big bitter ripe pomellated apples and END
BEGIN NOW chips of strawberries and sieves of gooseberries, pulpy and pelurious, END
BEGIN NOW and strawberries fit for princes and raspberries from their canes. END
BEGIN NOW I dare him, says he, and I doubledare him. END
BEGIN NOW Come out here, Geraghty, you END
BEGIN NOW notorious bloody hill and dale robber! END
BEGIN NOW And by that way wend the herds innumerable of bellwethers and flushed END
BEGIN NOW ewes and shearling rams and lambs and stubble geese and medium steers END
BEGIN NOW and roaring mares and polled calves and longwoods and storesheep and END
BEGIN NOW Cuffe's prime springers and culls and sowpigs and baconhogs and the END
BEGIN NOW various different varieties of highly distinguished swine and Angus END
BEGIN NOW heifers and polly bulllocks of immaculate pedigree together with prime END
BEGIN NOW premiated milchcows and beeves: and there is ever heard a trampling, END
BEGIN NOW cackling, roaring, lowing, bleating, bellowing, rumbling, grunting, END
BEGIN NOW champing, chewing, of sheep and pigs and heavyhooved kine from END
BEGIN NOW pasturelands of Lusk and Rush and Carrickmines and from the streamy END
BEGIN NOW vales of Thomond, from the M'Gillicuddy's reeks the inaccessible and END
BEGIN NOW lordly Shannon the unfathomable, and from the gentle declivities of the END
BEGIN NOW place of the race of Kiar, their udders distended with superabundance of END
BEGIN NOW milk and butts of butter and rennets of cheese and farmer's firkins and END
BEGIN NOW targets of lamb and crannocks of corn and oblong eggs in great hundreds, END
BEGIN NOW various in size, the agate with this dun. END
BEGIN NOW So we turned into Barney Kiernan's and there, sure enough, was the END
BEGIN NOW citizen up in the corner having a great confab with himself and that END
BEGIN NOW bloody mangy mongrel, Garryowen, and he waiting for what the sky would END
BEGIN NOW drop in the way of drink. END
BEGIN NOW —There he is, says I, in his gloryhole, with his cruiskeen lawn and his END
BEGIN NOW load of papers, working for the cause. END
BEGIN NOW The bloody mongrel let a grouse out of him would give you the creeps. END
BEGIN NOW Be END
BEGIN NOW a corporal work of mercy if someone would take the life of that bloody END
BEGIN NOW dog. END
BEGIN NOW I'm told for a fact he ate a good part of the breeches off a END
BEGIN NOW constabulary man in Santry that came round one time with a blue paper END
BEGIN NOW about a licence. END
BEGIN NOW —Stand and deliver, says he. END
BEGIN NOW —That's all right, citizen, says Joe. END
BEGIN NOW Friends here. END
BEGIN NOW —Pass, friends, says he. END
BEGIN NOW Then he rubs his hand in his eye and says he: END
BEGIN NOW —What's your opinion of the times? END
BEGIN NOW Doing the rapparee and Rory of the hill. END
BEGIN NOW But, begob, Joe was equal to END
BEGIN NOW the occasion. END
BEGIN NOW —I think the markets are on a rise, says he, sliding his hand down his END
BEGIN NOW fork. END
BEGIN NOW So begob the citizen claps his paw on his knee and he says: END
BEGIN NOW —Foreign wars is the cause of it. END
BEGIN NOW And says Joe, sticking his thumb in his pocket: END
BEGIN NOW —It's the Russians wish to tyrannise. END
BEGIN NOW —Arrah, give over your bloody codding, Joe, says I. END
BEGIN NOW I've a thirst on me END
BEGIN NOW I wouldn't sell for half a crown. END
BEGIN NOW —Give it a name, citizen, says Joe. END
BEGIN NOW —Wine of the country, says he. END
BEGIN NOW —What's yours? END
BEGIN NOW says Joe. END
BEGIN NOW —Ditto MacAnaspey, says I. END

BEGIN NOW And with that he took the bloody old towser by the scruff of the neck END
BEGIN NOW and, by Jesus, he near throttled him. END
BEGIN NOW The figure seated on a large boulder at the foot of a round tower was END
BEGIN NOW that of a broadshouldered deepchested stronglimbed frankeyed redhaired END
BEGIN NOW freelyfreckled shaggybearded widemouthed largenosed longheaded END
BEGIN NOW deepvoiced barekneed brawnyhanded hairylegged ruddyfaced sinewyarmed END
BEGIN NOW hero. END
BEGIN NOW From shoulder to shoulder he measured several ells and his END
BEGIN NOW rocklike mountainous knees were covered, as was likewise the rest of his END
BEGIN NOW body wherever visible, with a strong growth of tawny prickly hair in hue END
BEGIN NOW and toughness similar to the mountain gorse (Ulex Europeus). END
BEGIN NOW The END
BEGIN NOW widewinged nostrils, from which bristles of the same tawny hue END
BEGIN NOW projected, were of such capaciousness that within their cavernous END
BEGIN NOW obscurity the fieldlark might easily have lodged her nest. END
BEGIN NOW The eyes in END
BEGIN NOW which a tear and a smile strove ever for the mastery were of the END
BEGIN NOW dimensions of a goodsized cauliflower. END
BEGIN NOW A powerful current of warm breath END
BEGIN NOW issued at regular intervals from the profound cavity of his mouth while END
BEGIN NOW in rhythmic resonance the loud strong hale reverberations of his END
BEGIN NOW formidable heart thundered rumblingly causing the ground, the summit of END
BEGIN NOW the lofty tower and the still loftier walls of the cave to vibrate and END
BEGIN NOW tremble. END
BEGIN NOW He wore a long unsleeved garment of recently flayed oxhide reaching to END
BEGIN NOW the knees in a loose kilt and this was bound about his middle by a END
BEGIN NOW girdle of plaited straw and rushes. END
BEGIN NOW Beneath this he wore trews of END
BEGIN NOW deerskin, roughly stitched with gut. END
BEGIN NOW His nether extremities were encased END
BEGIN NOW in high Balbriggan buskins dyed in lichen purple, the feet being shod END
BEGIN NOW with brogues of salted cowhide laced with the windpipe of the same END
BEGIN NOW beast. END
BEGIN NOW From his girdle hung a row of seastones which jangled at every END
BEGIN NOW movement of his portentous frame and on these were graven with rude yet END
BEGIN NOW striking art the tribal images of many Irish heroes and heroines of END

BEGIN NOW Begob he was what you might call flabbergasted. END

BEGIN NOW taking the lout out for a walk. END
